story:
Scoop Marketplace is a zero-waste grocery store where customers fill reusable containers with our variety of package-free food, home goods, and personal care products. Our mission is to normalize zero waste shopping by teaching people how to improve the quality of their lives as they learn to walk more gently on the planet.

 

 

At Scoop Marketplace we provide a welcoming atmosphere where customers can conveniently shop in-store or online to purchase safe, high-quality food and home goods free from costly, inconvenient, and harmful packaging, and in whatever quantity they need or desire. We thoroughly research the vendors we work with and partner with businesses whose values align with our own.

 

 

Our products encourage sustainable living, our sourcing supports ethical businesses with an emphasis on small, local, and minority-owned, and we have the opportunity to work with businesses and consumers to normalize reusables. We are committed to finding innovative ways to offer this service while meeting the demands of our modern culture. Scoop Marketplace is the future of food, the way it used to be. 

 

 

 

Funding Goal is $32,000  

$18,000 Fridge & Freezer for Fresh Produce, Frozen Bulk Items like Local Berries & Cookie Dough, and Fresh Prepared Items such as Vegan Cheese, Sauerkraut & Salsas

$8,000 Nut Butter Grinder

$4,000 Draught Cooler for Beverages on Tap like Kombucha & Cold Brew 

$2,000 Upgraded Scales & Tare Deduction Technology for a more streamlined shopping experience

Reach Funding Goal $50,000

$6,000 Convection Oven for Fresh Baked Goods in the shop

$8,000 Grain Mills for fresh milled flours (one designated for gluten free)

$2,000 Nut Milk Machine

$2,000 Coffee Grinder

With the shop re-opening and growing rapidly, we are still in need of certain pieces of equipment to expand our offerings and become a full-service, package-free grocery store. The funds raised will be used to install equipment including refrigerators for produce and fresh bulk foods, a tap system for bulk oils/beverages, nut butter grinders, a coffee grinder, an oven for fresh baked goods, and an upgraded scale system to streamline our operations and provide an even better customer experience.

If we exceed our goal, we would like to install a full tap system to accommodate up to 20 different liquid bulk items on tap. Utilizing taps would allow us to maximize the storage space available in our back-of-house area and offer a very user-friendly experience in the front of house in order to expand our variety of liquid bulk items.

 

 

Every contribution helps! No donation amount is too small and we are grateful for each and every one. We're also partnering up with some of our favorite local businesses/brands to offer several 'perks' at various price points as a way to give back and say thank you! Here are a few examples:

Scoop Supporter ($15) - A water color print by a local artist that embodies the Scoop Marketplace mission to walk gently on the planet, a sustainably-sourced wooden Scoop Marketplace sticker.

  • Water color print card

  • Sustainably sourced wooden Scoop Marketplace sticker

 

The Caffeine Scoop ($50) - Enjoy coffee and donuts while visiting Scoop Marketplace!

  • A voucher for a vegan donut from Mighty O,
  • A punch card for 3 cups of coffee in the Scoop Marketplace shop,
  • A wooden Scoop Marketplace lapel pin

*Your Mighty O donut will be available for pick-up on 11/07 at Scoop Marketplace Kirkland.

 

Hygge EcoBox ($75) - Enjoy the feelings of coziness & comfortability with this seasonal sustainability box. In addition to your box items, this reward includes access to digital resources with information about each item, company, and how to properly care for and dispose of it at the end of its lifecycle. 

  • An eco-friendly cotton Turkish towel/blanket to cozy up in
  • Loose leaf tea and reusable cotton tea bags
  • Hand-poured soy candle
  • Cinnamon leaf essential oil 

 

Kitchen and Home EcoBox ($100) - Get a jump start on your zero-waste lifestyle with this Kitchen and Home EcoBox. This reward will include a large variety of sample-size items so that you can try various sustainable swaps before making a full commitment to any one product.

In addition to your box items, you will receive exclusive access to a live Q&A with Scoop Team Members, where they will discuss the different uses of each item.

Sample items include: 

  • Sample of Nellie’s cleaning products and Dropps pods
  • Scrub brush 
  • Eco-friendly dish soap
  • Toothpaste tabs
  • Roll of bamboo toilet paper
  • Vegan wax food wrap
  • No Trace reusable snack bag
  • Booda Soap, Shave & Shampoo bar sample
  • Shampoo bar sample
  • Swedish dishcloth
  • Small jar of all-purpose cleaning grains with a mini bottle
  • Bamboo pot scraper

 

Plantiful Holiday Feast ($150) - Stephanie’s brand new digital cooking course guides you in making a fully plant-based meal to share with your loved one for this holiday season. You'll also receive a box of goodies to help you make your holiday feast including spices, utensils, and a few other surprises. Plus you'll get access to an additional cooking video for making Jack O'Lantern Pie. We’re working together to build new traditions for a sustainable and truly delicious future! 

  • Recipes and instruction videos for 1 entree, 5 sides, and 1 dessert
  • Grocery lists and calendars to help you plan your meal
  • Tips to minimize kitchen waste
  • Jack O'Lantern Pie recipe and video
  • Box of goodies: spices, sustainable kitchen utensils, and other surprises!

*You'll receive access to the digital course on Nov 2nd and boxes will be shipped by Nov 8th.

 

Beauty EcoBox ($200) - Beauty product sampler box with access to video with clips from a few of our partners talking about the products and why they use the ingredients that they do. 

  • Beauty sampler box
  • Special video access 

 

Super Community Member ($400) - Get your name on our community recycling center that will be located within Scoop Marketplace Kirkland as well as a one-year Scoop founding membership which includes: annual membership price locked in for life, 5% discount on all Scoop purchases, access to digital sustainability downloads, first look at our sustainability report, pre-order access for new products and more! This reward also includes Scoop Canvas Tote Bag with Bulk shopping kit, & lapel pin.

  • Scoop Founding Membership
  • Name on our recycling center
  • Scoop Canvas Tote Bag
  • Bulk Shopping Kit
  • Scoop Lapel Pin

 

VIP ($3000) - VIP Customized zero-waste kitchen session. Custom consultation with our one and only founder, Stephanie, on Zoom. Go through your kitchen and get help bringing your home or office's footprint down. Includes a customized kit of zero-waste resources based on your needs that will total $1000 worth of product. *This may or may not include a Scoop gift card for the remaining value depending on your specific needs.

  • VIP Zero-Waste Kitchen Session

  • Customized Kit of Zero-Waste Products ($1,000 value)

  • Scoop Gift Card for any remaining sum after kit

 

 

 

The average American creates 4.5 pounds of garbage each day. We purchase disposable products that are made to be used for a few minutes but will remain on Earth forever. Due to increased awareness of our climate crisis, people are ready to reduce their waste and consumption of single-use plastics, but our linear economy makes this task feel impossible.

 

We want to clean up the environment, create a circular economy, and enjoy healthy, thriving lives. We will do this one step at a time and adjusting a daily routine like grocery shopping is a great start.

 

 

Our community appreciates our commitment to providing a judgment-free environment and the way in which we prioritize taking imperfect action. People do want to make these changes, but it is difficult to prioritize sustainable living in our current culture. We provide educational opportunities, like our podcast, Green Stuff, and a safe place to try things out a little at a time and find what fits best into each individual’s definition of a sustainable lifestyle.

 

 

The most important work that we do is education. From our zero waste lifestyle tips that we share on our podcast every Tuesday to our blog posts, weekly emails, full-length podcast episodes, and even the e-learning opportunities that we provide through the digital side of our business, Scoop Intelligence, we are always looking for ways to teach people how they too can improve the quality of their lives while learning to walk more gently on the planet. 

 

 

We want to show that it doesn’t have to be extremely expensive or inconvenient or uncomfortable and that these small, intentional shifts can not only improve your quality of life but contribute to the creation of a sustainable future in which all of us can truly thrive. 

 

 

 

Your support can go a long way. Like us on Instagram / Facebook and spread the word by tagging us in posts, re-sharing what we're up to, and following us along the way.

Instagram: www.instagram.com/ScoopMarketplace

www.instagram.com/ScoopIntelligence

Facebook: www.facebook.com/ScoopMarketplace 

www.facebook.com/ScoopIntelligence

 

 

Visit us at www.ScoopMarketplace.com

 

 

Scoop In The News

King 5 News - Scoop Marketplace, a zero-waste grocery store, opens in Kirkland

https://www.king5.com/article/features/scoop-marketplace-a-zero-waste-grocery-store-opens-in-kirkland/281-90d97c8e-a6b4-42e7-b85f-c6d839b2d008?fbclid=IwAR1V6zHOSM2J0TwMZN5ATjlYG0bkCOAFeziW0mJEqVxyrneXVGd4OHAR6bU

Kirkland Reporter - Scoop Marketplace looks to cut waste out of grocery economy

https://www.kirklandreporter.com/news/scoop-marketplace-looks-to-cut-waste-out-of-grocery-economy/?fbclid=IwAR2FWhkG2Kn0ksCwqkkF2XQT1cbJieicBzeW5wTTFX1XR6TzJiTWngQaKhA

 

 

425 Magazine - Zero-Waste Grocery Store to Open New Kirkland Location

https://www.425magazine.com/arts-entertainment/zero-waste-grocery-store-to-open-new-kirkland-location/article_71fd083a-8d41-5806-bd51-f6ae2417c172.html#0_5_9434_8275_2535_227287566

 

Kirkland Weblog - Check Out Scoop Marketplace for Zero Waste Groceries

https://www.kirklandweblog.com/kirkland_weblog/2021/10/check-out-scoop-marketplace-for-zero-waste-groceries.html

An eco-friendly cotton Turkish towel/blanket to cozy up in
Loose leaf tea and reusable cotton tea bags
Hand-poured soy candle
Cinnamon leaf essential oil 

 

Kitchen and Home EcoBox ($100) - Get a jump start on your zero-waste lifestyle with this Kitchen and Home EcoBox. This reward will include a large variety of sample-size items so that you can try various sustainable swaps before making a full commitment to any one product.
In addition to your box items, you will receive exclusive access to a live Q&A with Scoop Team Members, where they will discuss the different uses of each item.
Sample items include: 

Sample of Nellie’s cleaning products and Dropps pods
Scrub brush 
Eco-friendly dish soap
Toothpaste tabs
Roll of bamboo toilet paper
Vegan wax food wrap
No Trace reusable snack bag
Booda Soap, Shave & Shampoo bar sample
Shampoo bar sample
Swedish dishcloth
Small jar of all-purpose cleaning grains with a mini bottle
Bamboo pot scraper

 

Plantiful Holiday Feast ($150) - Stephanie’s brand new digital cooking course guides you in making a fully plant-based meal to share with your loved one for this holiday season. You'll also receive a box of goodies to help you make your holiday feast including spices, utensils, and a few other surprises. Plus you'll get access to an additional cooking video for making Jack O'Lantern Pie. We’re working together to build new traditions for a sustainable and truly delicious future! 

Recipes and instruction videos for 1 entree, 5 sides, and 1 dessert
Grocery lists and calendars to help you plan your meal
Tips to minimize kitchen waste
Jack O'Lantern Pie recipe and video
Box of goodies: spices, sustainable kitchen utensils, and other surprises!

*You'll receive access to the digital course on Nov 2nd and boxes will be shipped by Nov 8th.
 

Beauty EcoBox ($200) - Beauty product sampler box with access to video with clips from a few of our partners talking about the products and why they use the ingredients that they do. 

Beauty sampler box
Special video access 

 

Super Community Member ($400) - Get your name on our community recycling center that will be located within Scoop Marketplace Kirkland as well as a one-year Scoop founding membership which includes: annual membership price locked in for life, 5% discount on all Scoop purchases, access to digital sustainability downloads, first look at our sustainability report, pre-order access for new products and more! This reward also includes Scoop Canvas Tote Bag with Bulk shopping kit, & lapel pin.

Scoop Founding Membership
Name on our recycling center
Scoop Canvas Tote Bag
Bulk Shopping Kit
Scoop Lapel Pin

 

VIP ($3000) - VIP Customized zero-waste kitchen session. Custom consultation with our one and only founder, Stephanie, on Zoom. Go through your kitchen and get help bringing your home or office's footprint down. Includes a customized kit of zero-waste resources based on your needs that will total $1000 worth of product. *This may or may not include a Scoop gift card for the remaining value depending on your specific needs.

VIP Zero-Waste Kitchen Session
Customized Kit of Zero-Waste Products ($1,000 value)
Scoop Gift Card for any remaining sum after kit

 


 

 
The average American creates 4.5 pounds of garbage each day. We purchase disposable products that are made to be used for a few minutes but will remain on Earth forever. Due to increased awareness of our climate crisis, people are ready to reduce their waste and consumption of single-use plastics, but our linear economy makes this task feel impossible.
 
We want to clean up the environment, create a circular economy, and enjoy healthy, thriving lives. We will do this one step at a time and adjusting a daily routine like grocery shopping is a great start.
 

 
Our community appreciates our commitment to providing a judgment-free environment and the way in which we prioritize taking imperfect action. People do want to make these changes, but it is difficult to prioritize sustainable living in our current culture. We provide educational opportunities, like our podcast, Green Stuff, and a safe place to try things out a little at a time and find what fits best into each individual’s definition of a sustainable lifestyle.
 

 
The most important work that we do is education. From our zero waste lifestyle tips that we share on our podcast every Tuesday to our blog posts, weekly emails, full-length podcast episodes, and even the e-learning opportunities that we provide through the digital side of our business, Scoop Intelligence, we are always looking for ways to teach people how they too can improve the quality of their lives while learning to walk more gently on the planet. 
 

 
We want to show that it doesn’t have to be extremely expensive or inconvenient or uncomfortable and that these small, intentional shifts can not only improve your quality of life but contribute to the creation of a sustainable future in which all of us can truly thrive. 
 


 


 
Your support can go a long way. Like us on Instagram / Facebook and spread the word by tagging us in posts, re-sharing what we're up to, and following us along the way.
Instagram: www.instagram.com/ScoopMarketplace
www.instagram.com/ScoopIntelligence
Facebook: www.facebook.com/ScoopMarketplace 
www.facebook.com/ScoopIntelligence
 

 
Visit us at www.ScoopMarketplace.com

story:
JokeKeeper: A $1,000,000 fund to hire satirists, creatives and producers to make ads and content ridiculing our fossil fuel supporting political parties. Just in time for a crucial election. Get angry and chip in!

This will include but not be limited to:

  • Billboards that we've already designed and funded as well as new ideas.
  • Using robust data science to target satirical comedy videos mocking incumbent politicians who are beholden to fossil fuel donations.
  • Pranks: Like the Capital Empathy College. A pop up store in Cronulla where visitors can learn empathy in under an hour.

  • The Brass Plaque initiative: We're going to be making 100 Brass Plaques that say "During a National Crisis — Prime Minister of Australia Stood Upon This Spot And Did Nothing" These will be sent all over Australia and Hawaii.

  • ​Australian Government Against Humanity: We're going to make an expansion pack for CAH where you can throw in the dumbest solutions to Australia's most pressing problems.

$1,000,000 isn't a lot to build a team of 30-40 master sh**stirers to work for three months.

Here's other things $1m can buy.

  • Approval of a $60b coal mine
  • 1 day in court of a defamation trial that you started and decided to end but definitely didn't lose.
  • 1/6 of a Car Park in Kooyong.
  • 1/3 of a Rugby league change room in North Queensland.
  • 1 episode of Ted Lasso.

See — if just 1000 people give $1000 so a bunch of comedians and filmmakers who have been out of work for two years have the opportunity to make certain ministers regret not replying to an email from Pfizer — so that they can help get some climate action for the 7 billion people that live on this Earth — It'll all be worth it.

Cheers

 

Dan

 

 

 

UPDATE 28/09: We met our initial target in 2.5 hours and we're now on the hunt for bigger billboards and more billboards, not just in Glasgow but around Australia.

We're also trying to get on to the roster for motion projection of the SEC Armadillo where COP26 is being held . If we do that, we'll need to hire a few motion graphics designers to build out animation to fit this incredible building!

 

INITIAL CAMPAIGN:


In November Australia will be heading the COP26 climate conference in Glasgow. This is where the entire world gets together and tries to workout how they can stay on track with the Paris Agreement so the world doesn't end in a flammable meat ball, as it is currently on trend to do.

And the number one enemy at these talks — is Australia.

Australia is famous at these talks for cheating, lying and giving fake commitments. But this time it's different, the world's most powerful governments aren't buying any of our b******t.

So the Australian Government is about to spend a tonne of money on ads to tell the world how much they’re investing in climate action and how much they’ve lowered their emissions, and spin up language and terms of phrase to make it LOOK like Australia has done something. When in-fact Australia has gone backwards over the last 15 years on climate action.

So we’re going to buy 3 Glaswegian billboards during the Climate talks to set Australia's record straight and to let the world know that the people at the talks representing Australia don’t represent Australians.

 

We have two Billboards ready to go —

Cuddle A Koala! (Before we make them extinct)
By Brisbane artist Nordacious 

And Australia: Net-0 Emissions by 2300

And the 3rd billboard is up to a generous donor — maybe you?

 

These Billboards are EXPENSIVE and we need your help to make it happen.

It’s going to cost $12,225 to get to get them up for 14 days during the Climate Talks 

 

BIG REWARDS!

If you give more than $150 or more you’ll get a sticker pack of the billboards you financed.

 

If you give more than $500 or more you’ll get your name around the border of a billboard.

 

And if you give $4000 you can decide what goes on the 3rd billboard — Let's talk!

 

So instead of getting angry that Australia is lying to the world on your behalf, the only responsible thing to do as a good Australian citizen is to tell the truth.

Be a part of something funny, powerful and  help us show leadership to the people that should be leading us.

CHIP IN!

story:
Overview

There are 20 polluting salmon farms in the Clayoquot Sound UNESCO Biosphere Region. Meanwhile, wild salmon in Clayoquot Sound are rapidly sliding towards extinction—with returning spawners counts in single digits at many rivers near Tofino. It’s not too late to stop this—but we need your help. Our Clayoquot Salmon Investigation (CSI) program gets staff and volunteers out on the water monitoring fish farms in order to expose this industry’s dirty secrets. We’ve been able to expose pesticide dumping, sea lice outbreaks, and deadly Norwegian viruses at fish farms near Tofino.

Momentum is building to get salmon farms out of Clayoquot Sound. All federal salmon farm licenses in BC will expire in 2022, and the federal government has committed to getting the farms out of BC waters by 2025. Now more than ever is the time to keep an eye on this harmful industry, and keep the story in the news.

Clayoquot Sound is the largest ancient rainforest left on Vancouver Island. Nearly a thousand people were arrested here at the peaceful logging blockades of the 1990s. Now it’s time to step up to protect the wild salmon that fertilize the trees and feed bears, wolves, and people.

Support this campaign to help keep Clayoquot Sound wild and majestic. These are salmon forests. We are salmon people.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Clayoquot Salmon Investigation (CSI) is our salmon farm watchdog program. During COVID the Department of Fisheries has cut monitoring, making this grassroots program more important than ever before. And now, Cermaq (a subsidiary of Mitsubishi Corp.) has installed a new experimental fish farm in Millar Channel near Ahousat, posing new threats that must be monitored and exposed.

Clayoquot Salmon Investigation gets out on the water near Tofino to keep an eye on this secretive industry, which otherwise operates out of sight, out of mind. We've been able to expose stories which no-one would have heard about, such as mass die-offs, viral outbreaks, pesticide dumping, and sea lice epidemics; we then get those stories in the news to build political pressure.

Our Going Viral project (thank you to everyone who contributed to our 2019 Indiegogo!) was able to expose the fact that all but one salmon farm tested in Clayoquot Sound was contaminated with the deadly Norwegian piscine orthoreovirus (PRV).

We travel deep into the inlets, year-round in all weather, to collect samples and monitor what's happening on the ground. This year, we'll be paying special attention to the new experimental farm. We’ve been able to break national news stories many times, exposing these companies’ awful environmental practices.

Your donation will power up CSI by putting gas in volunteers' boats, chartering boats when necessary, sending samples to the lab for testing, and helping with the costs of equipment and video production to help spread the word.

Donate generously and get great perks in return!

 


 

The Impact

Clayoquot Sound is the largest and most famous ancient rainforest left on Vancouver Island in British Columbia, Canada. The Clayoquot Summer blockades of 1993 which stopped the chainsaws were then the largest act of civil disobedience in Canadian history (a record held until this summer—way to go Fairy Creek protectors!).

'The War of the Woods' in Clayoquot Sound—Canada's second largest act of civil disobedience.

Yet entire ecosystems are being put at risk by open-net pen salmon farms. Wild salmon runs which used to return to spawn in the tens of thousands, now only return in tens. If wild salmon go the way of the dodo, wildlife will starve and so will the forests. Local Indigenous cultures will be impoverished.

Clayoquot Salmon Investigation shines a spotlight on the local face of the global salmon farming industry. In past we have been successful in breaking media stories about Creative Salmon’s tainted bloodwater discharge into Tofino Harbour; as well as Cermaq’s mass die-offs, a sea lion massacre, sea lice epidemics, and their controversial chemical warfare to manage their sea lice crisis. We were able to pressure the BC government to investigate all pesticide use on fish farms in BC, as well as all blood water discharge from fish processing plants.

All of these stories in the news are showing people that salmon farming is clearly not sustainable. A 2021 pre-election poll showed that 75% of British Columbians want salmon farms removed from the ocean.

Now there is serious momentum to get the farms out! In 2018 Washington state banned salmon farms from their waters by 2022. The same year, British Columbia announced that salmon farms will be removed from the Broughton Archipelago by 2022. Canada's government pledged in 2019 to transition from open-net pen salmon farms to closed containment by 2025—and the transition has already begun in the Discovery Islands. This leaves all eyes on Clayoquot as the largest remaining concentration of fish farms in BC.

Clayoquot Action is calling for salmon farms to be removed from Clayoquot Sound immediately. Please join the movement to help make this happen! You can help protect wild salmon—the backbone of the coast.

 

Check out the perks!

Contribute to this campaign and stay right on the beach in Tofino at Long Beach Lodge! 

Surf-in surf-out accommodations generously donated by Long Beach Lodge!

 

There is also some incredible west coast art available like this 11x14 print.

 

The Yeti Action Pack includes a CA hoodie, a Yeti Rambler mug, a Patagonia truckers hat & sticker. Mugs donated by Tofino Resort and Marina. Hats donated by Patagonia Vancouver.

 

Canadian-made & Fairtrade eco-friendly bamboo hoodie is as soft as they come! Featuring the Clayoquot Action logo on the back and chest. Unisex fit. Women may prefer to order one
size smaller.

 

Our unisex t-shirts look great and are made with soft 100% cotton! Large logo on the back and small logo on the front chest. 

 

Bring a piece of Clayoquot Sound into your home with a 20" x 27" limited edition reproduction of Leanne Hodges' wolf and salmon painting. The giclée is printed on canvas which gives it that ‘real painting’ feel. Ready to hang.

 

Hand made on Clayoquot Island, these all natural soaps make for a great gift!

 

What if we exceed our goal?

By joining Clayoquot Action’s Indiegogo community you will be helping to get salmon farms out of the oceans in British Columbia.

 If the goal of raising $10,000 is exceeded, here are a few items from the top of our to-do list: 

$5,000 will power up our campaign to ban pesticide use on salmon farms in Clayoquot Sound.

$15,000 will power up our work to help prevent a sea lice epidemic in 2022.

$45,000 will hire a full-time CSI field and researcher coordinator for a year to help get polluting salmon farms out of Clayoquot Sound!

 

Who is Clayoquot Action?

Clayoquot Action stands for democratic rights, Indigenous rights, and the rights of Mother Earth. Together with local volunteers and a small staff—backed online by people around the world—we run strategic, people-powered campaigns to help Clayoquot Sound remain one of the most beautiful places left on earth.

Clayoquot Action founders Bonny Glambeck and Dan Lewis were key organizers of the 1993 Clayoquot Summer protests. For over thirty years, they have been working to protect this awe-inspiring place from threats due to clearcut logging, industrial-scale mining, oil tankers, and salmon farming. See a visual timeline of their history here. 

What is Clayoquot Sound?

Clayoquot Sound UNESCO Biosphere Region, near Tofino BC, is the Last Great Rainforest on Vancouver Island—world famous for monumental cedars, bears, wolves and whales.

Clayoquot Action recognizes and supports the Indigenous rights and title of the Hesquiaht, Ahousaht, and Tla-o-qui-aht First Nations—stewards since time immemorial of the lands and waters now called Clayoquot Sound.

The nitrogen which fertilizes these magnificent rainforests comes from a marine source—in the bodies of wild salmon, when they return to their natal stream to spawn and die. Black bears, timber wolves, bald eagles and many other wildlife species feast on the salmon, spreading the nutrients far and wide.

Wild salmon are the lifeblood of these ancient forests and cultures, providing food, livelihoods and fertilizing the ecosystem which sustains life.

A fish farm in Clayoquot Sound experiencing a Hazardous Algae Bloom. 

 

Want to learn more?

Check out ClayoquotAction.org and take the Wild Salmon Pledge. You'll be kept up to date on the latest developments, and you'll be the first to know when you can take specific actions to help protect wild salmon.

Other Ways You Can Help

Follow Clayoquot Action on social media. Please help us promote this campaign—share this page with your family and friends!

- Clayoquot Action on Instagram

- Clayoquot Action on Facebook

- Clayoquot Action on Twitter

Please help us promote this campaign—share this page with your family and friends!- Clayoquot Action on Instagram- Clayoquot Action on Facebook- Clayoquot Action on Twitter

story:
Help Saving the Oceans from Plastic!

Help us print 1000 books to educate kids on plastic in our oceans. The book is for 5 - 13 year olds & comes in English, Swedish & Danish for now.

By now we all know about plastic in our oceans - it's our kids that will see the devastating results. We want to educate them to help them understand how they can actually cause the change & live in a word with a healthy thriving oceans.

The book is a cute story made to educate and inspire little ocean heroes & have lots of great facts as well.

 

Project Short Summary

We are Sandra & Joe and together we have 3 kids Alfie, Angelica & Elias. (7, 5 & 7 years old)

We are all deeply passionate about the oceans and trying to live a plastic free life as much as possible. We are freedivers and photographers who while watching the amazing Plastic Oceans documentary with our kids, Elias burst out "We have to do something to help the oceans" and so we did. We have done many beach cleanups but quickly realised like Angelica said: "We can't keep doing this every day" - So we decided to write a Childrens book to educate and inspire the new gerneration & their parents to help save the ocean from plastic pollution by prevention. 

2 years of hard work later this book is now ready!

Educating the new generation on plastic pollution is essential to end it and it's what we want to do through this childrensbook. Throughout the book there are facts about the ocean, plastic and the animals as well as a great story of the three kids that will inspire your little ones to become ocean heroes themselves.

The book is ready but we need help with printing it, so we would love your support to make it happen & for you to of course get a copy yourself.

 

Book Languages:

ENGLISH - SWEDISH & DANISH

The book is originally in English but we also print swedish and a danish version now. 

We will send it to you in the language that fits your address otherwise please do let me know by email: info@sandraaberg.com your preferred language!

Please let's know if you want another language.

 

What is the book about?

The book takes you from the city where a little boy Elias lives - he finds out he has a super power to hold his breath under water. It's about how he with Alfie and Angelica set out to save the oceans on a vacation to Italy and how they meet the animals that tells them about the problems of the plastic. It's illustrated to inspire with beautiful images, not as a scare campaign - rather a way to show what can be done now. It's also about  blended families and the joy of coming together for a bigger purpose. 

THGE BOOK IS GREAT FOR KIDS 5-13 YEARS OLD - but even younger can enjoy the images,

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We need €8,500 to publish, print and distribute the children's book, so it reaches as many homes as possible and help educate and inspire the new generation.
  • Of course we want you to also have and read the book so we will make sure you get a copy too. (backers 24€ and up)

 

The Impact

This book can change how we look at plastic and how it impacts the oceans, both for the little ones and the parents.

Small steps to big change is what we believe in.

With the participation of the kids we wrote a children's book to promote awareness on plastic pollution in the oceans, to inspire children and their parents into becoming ocean heroes, which inspires so many little and big souls to care of our oceans and limit the use of plastic

​

Challenges

Despite a steep learning curve and this being our first book we are now finally ready to print the book in English and Swedish & can also be ordered in Danish for those who want. We could not have done this without the amazing help from family and friends that all believed in the project. Last but certainly not least a huge thank you to the amazing illustrations by Maria Kirshina, she was as if sent from heaven. Many great friends also supported and helped us, like our colleague Jakob Æbeløe Kjøller. We looked for the perfect illustrator for over 6 months before finding Maria and magic happened when she got on board with her amazing drawing skills.

We have had great support and are so thrilled to finally be ready to print the book.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We would've for you to fund and back the book project and read the book to your kids - your grandkids or friends. Sharing is super important too.

We would love your help in other ways too: 

  • Help us make some noise and share about the project! Please use the Indiegogo share tools.
  • Any knowledge you have about publishing a children's book is welcome. 
  • Organise a beach cleanup where you are!

We hope you will want to support us and help us help the oceans free of plastic pollution by educating our new generations! <3 

So very thankful for all your help.

HUGS

Sandra, Joe & the kids Alfie, Elias & Angelica.

Follow us on Instagram; @plastic_oceans_book

story:
Leveling up!

For the last 18 months we've been growing and collecting food and yard waste from community members.  It started as 12 of us and has grown to 270 members today.  In that time we've diverted 40,000 pounds of waste from landfills.  We want to keep growing and in order to do so, we need some more space and machinery.  We have an agreement to provide us some space and once we get there, then we'll have to prepare the site and have a way of moving compost around.  That's where the machinery comes in.

Hi!

I'm Bob Mattax.  I work with software by trade, but enjoy all things outdoors and want to do something to make a lasting impact in my community and environment. It turns out ScrapCycle is doing that and I'm hoping that we can keep growing and keep growing our impact to more and more communities in Indiana, and someday beyond.   We have adopted a pretty non-capitalist business model.  Nobody is mandated to pay, but we ask that you pay as much as you can.  Generally, this makes our reach greater, but are cash flow suffers.  That's mostly ok, BUT... for the purpose of this grant, we want to maximize how much we're able to push in, so that we also maximize what we get out.

What do we want to buy?

I'm glad you asked.  We are in the process of getting a new composting site approved by the state.  Once that is done, we will have a bunch of stuff we need:

  • $5,000  = We need concrete blocks and money to rent machines to move them around and create our "space".  Grading the site and creating a retention pond and some other site infrastructure
  • $14,000 = We need money to buy a "gently" used tractor.  If we can swing it, we're going to buy it from another non-profit in town ( Farmished ) so that they instantly get a boost from this fundraiser as well.
  • $1,000 = We want to buy some fancy, sealed, compost toters to provide to commercial clients so that we can start approaching big compost creating businesses ( like coffee shops, restaurants, etc ) 

The Impact

Every month we're diverting 2 tons of compost from landfills.  The emissions math works out that that is about the same as stopping approximately 300 gallons of gasoline from being burned.  It only gets better as we are able to service more and more homes and businesses.

If you can't help financially... please share

  • Post something on your social media and help us get attention beyond just our immediate circles.

 

THANK YOU!! 

I hope in the small amount of time that we have that we'll be able to do some amazing fundraising and reach these goals.

story:
What is Women in Climate Tech (WiCT)?

A growing number of entrepreneurs, investors, and technology executives are rising to meet the challenge of climate change. Women in Climate Tech is an international network dedicated to helping women and nonbinary people in this work.

Since our founding in December 2020, our platform has grown to 400+ members and 750 subscribers from businesses, academia, and sustainability offices at some of the largest businesses in the world, including Microsoft, Google, Amazon, and more.

What's your mission? 

Our mission is to empower and amplify the voices of women working in the industry, and to grow the share of women represented who will work on this issue for generations to come.

Why does gender matter?

Emerging research shows the critical importance of gender in climate change work, and the impact of empowering women in developing countries and in the corporate world.

Can you give me some numbers?

If women had the same access to productive resources as men, they would increase farm yields by 20-30%, increasing the wealth and health of their families and their country’s GDPs.  Project Drawdown found that supporting women as smallholder-farmers could reduce 2.1 gigatons of carbon dioxide by 2050. 

Furthermore, while 129 million girls worldwide are denied an education, Project Drawdown’s research reveals that educating girls around the world results in actual carbon emission reduction. 

Meanwhile, a study of 11,700 companies revealed that companies with higher than 30% women on their boards had better climate governance globally. Gender-diverse boards invested more in renewable power generation and energy efficiency. And as domestic and international calls for greater transparency and regulation in climate risk reporting grow, research shows that organizations with gender-diverse boards have better environmental reporting and climate governance than their peers. 

All in all, evolving research shows that in every country and every economic sector, amplifying women’s voices may be crucial to addressing climate change.

As such, interest in the venture community for women-owned climate tech businesses is growing. So is demand from large businesses who are looking to grow and staff climate change departments. Women in Climate Tech is filling a unique niche, connecting women with funding as well as jobs in the space.

What have you done so far?

To date, WiCT has:

  • Hosted seven events thus far, with speakers ranging from NASA scientist Dr. Kimberly Miner to Audrey Scott of TED Talk fame. 
  • Grown a LinkedIn group and dedicated Slack Channel as resources for sharing ideas and opportunities. Several members have reported to us that they have secured new career opportunities, and several venture capitalists have begun talks with startups in our network as a direct result of our group’s activities.
  • Launched advocacy campaigns, including in support of the Women in Climate Change Act of 2021. Our efforts garnered a personal note of support from Rep. Barbara Lee, creator of the Women in Climate Change Act, as well as broad support through professional networks and a LinkedIn campaign for the legislation.
  • Built a first-of-its-kind initiative to pioneer a research project to bake equity into climate risk reporting. Dubbed the TECFD, the initiative brings together women from around the world, from the fields of science, finance, analytics, and more, with the goal of building a toolkit for businesses and governments to enhance the effectiveness of Net Zero work through diversity. WiCT has been invited to present this work at New York’s Climate Week in September, and at the World Humanitarian Forum in NYC at the side of the UN General Assembly.

What’s the bottom line?

Gender equality is critical to achieving net zero, yet this fact is seldom discussed in media, science or business. Given that:

  • Women and girls are far more susceptible to the impacts of climate change— 80% of individuals displaced by climate change around the globe are women, and women and children are 14 times more likely to die from extreme weather; and
  • Elevating women and girls has been found to be a ‘climate solutions multiplier,’ that increases the effectiveness of all other climate change efforts,
  • Women in Climate Tech’s research, advocacy, and programming empowers champions gender equality to harness this pragmatic and powerful solution to the defining problem of our time.

Where will my donation go?

All funds will support the development and growth of Women in Climate Tech.

I can’t donate. Is there another way I can help?

If you can't make a monetary contribution, please consider:

  • Sharing our campaign to your LinkedIn and Facebook pages
  • Following our LinkedIn page for updates on events and projects 
  • Keeping an eye on our applications page as we look for new members
  • Signing up for our newsletter

story:
We are a group of diverse humans creating an integrated, mutifaceted farm that serves multiple purposes, including:

• Ecological benefits for rivers, groundwater, soil, habitat creation, wildlife food, insectaries , carbon sink

• Welcoming beautiful food-producing landscapes for our community, including natural playgrounds and hide-outs

• Outdoor teaching and learning space

• Opportunities for participation 

• An abundance of food to share - our fresh vegetables are donated to the Kennett Food Cupboard.

This spring, we got the approval from Kennett Township to move our operation onto public land at Spar Hill Farm. While we have been hard at work, there are many things still missing to turn this first year into a bountiful success.

story:
Ultimate field guide on Australian plants their relationships within ecosystems and repairing the land.  

We are really excited to announce that pre-orders for renowned bush ethno-botanist and native plant author Neville Bonney's forthcoming book, From One Small Seed a Forest is Born are now open.   

By purchasing a copy, you will contribute to the publishing and printing costs of the First Edition of One Small Seed a Forest is Born. You’ll also receive a special First Edition Hardcover signed copy from the author, Neville Bonney posted to your address.  

This comprehensive field guide, (close to 600 pages) is about Australian Native Plants and their seeds. Fully illustrated in colour, features identification through flowers, fruits and seeds in scale size, some 700 species from 63 families and 240 genera, complemented with photos in the field on Australian landscapes, birds, ants, butterflies, bees and much more.  

Most species entered have detailed descriptions, distribution maps, details on their pollinators, seed dispersal, seed collection, propagation, ecology and Indigenous names and uses.  

It helps the reader to gain further knowledge to help restore ecosystems and landscapes. There are also introductory notes on our changing landscapes, history and other related topics.  

Neville's knowledge of Indigenous plants gained through his many friendships and collaborations with Aboriginal people while researching and writing his books is also recorded. How plants were used traditionally for food, medicine and tools are explained for hundreds of plant species. 

From One Small Seed a Forest is Born also provides important information about plant associations with fauna and fungi. We are confident in saying that there has yet to be a book published in Australia that conveys with such clarity the interrelationships present in Australia's land eco-systems. 

Neville’s work has been ably assisted by an advisory group formed in Feb 2018 to support him to bring the book to publication. It is believed that this collaborative ‘citizen science’ approach to producing a field guide is quite unique. 

This book will be the ideal companion for plant enthusiasts, those eager to protect and restore Australia’s ecosystems or travellers who want to know about our landscapes as they explore this great wide land.   

From One Small Seed a Forest is Born - Contents 

How to use this book 

Introduction 

Forewords – Professor Chris Daniels and Ngarrindjeri Elders,  Aunty Ellen Trevorrow and Uncle Doug Nicholls

Book Endorsements – National perspective 

Chronological overview of changing Australian Landscape 

Fungi (Indicator for soil health) 

Ecological Sustainable Landscapes 

Importance of Seed Genetics, including flora guidelines 

Flower Pollinators 

Seed dispersal agents 

Knowing Australian Native Plant Seed  

Native seed viability and germinability 

Germination of Native Plant Seed 

Native Plant Seed and its relationship to fire 

From Seed to Seed (when and when not to burn the bush) 

Plant Families 1-64 

Glossary and terms used within this book 

Bibliography 

Acknowledgements 

About the Author 

Index

story:
We are a for-profit social venture, internationally we are establishing butterfly farming in various third-world communities to alleviate poverty and promote environmental protection. Domestically we are establishing a live entomology education and cultural center in San Diego County to increase environmental and cultural awareness.


In our co-op communities the needs we are trying to meet include the need for a reliable income that is sustainable, renewable and not reliant upon the destruction of natural resources, the need for an infrastructure that provides the opportunity for social and economic growth, and the need for entrepreneurial empowerment.


1.  Create a sustainable income for third world communities through the implementation of a butterfly farming Co-op. By supplementing the farmers’ income with an alternative occupation, we increase income levels. According to recent records from the Amani Butterfly Project Report, an increase of 25% in income was indicated for participating butterfly farmers. This vastly improves the quality of life for individuals, allowing children to attend school and for families to be able to pay for secondary school. 


When asked about what benefits they had received from butterfly farming, one farmer stated, “We are living a good life in my family. I have bought a bicycle, I have bricks, I have bought the grills for the windows of my house, iron sheets, and timber. I am able to pay school fees for my children.” (Farm Radio International, 2009).

By giving them all the tools they need to succeed, from production materials such as equipment and training, to business tools such as business classes and workshops, we empower these communities to become financially successful and independent.

2. Community development. As a community co-op, we aim to reduce attrition from the program by allocating ten percent of sales to community projects which will be chosen by local members of the co-op community. This investment back into the community ensures that the implementation of the butterfly farms will be not only smooth, but also beneficial to all members of the community regardless of their participation.

3.  Reduce the need of third world communities to deplete their natural resources and destroy biodiversity. By providing farmers with an alternative income, we reduce the need for slash and burn farming.The environmentally friendly production of butterflies demands that habitats be in as pristine condition as possible. 

Below image taken from :"Butterfly farming and conservation behavior in the East Usambara Mountains of Tanzania" by Theron Morgan-Brown, 2007.

This need for pristine environments encourages locals to halt deforestation or even reverse the damage that has been done because the farmers increased income is dependent upon this pristine environment. This creates an economic incentive to conserve.


We plan on establishing our first co-op within the first 8 months of operation. This co-op will be established with the target size of around 60 to 80 participating butterfly farmers. We anticipate that at the start of our co-op a 40 to 50 percent participation rate will indicate successful dissemination into the community, as well as positive reception of the co-op, paving the way for success.

We aim to benefit the community directly, as 10 percent of pupae sales income will be invested in community improvement projects. Other successful projects have shown that as the success of the butterfly farming becomes more obvious, the community support grows within the first two to three years to encompass 80 to 90 percent of the families.

Within two years after the initiation of our first co-op, we intend to take our experience to two additional communities, bringing the positive economic and environmental impacts to new communities. Therefore, we plan to triple our economic, community, and environmental impacts within two year of initiation. Within two years, the breadth of our impact will increase dramatically. However, our focus is to impact a few individuals and communities at an extraordinarily deep level by improving their quality of life.

Our plan after several successful butterfly farming co-ops is our domestic social impact. This involves the inception of the San Diego Butterfly Zoo cultural and environmental center, which will exhibit many of the beautiful butterflies that our co-op farmers produce. The goal of this facility complements that of the co-ops, in that it intends to have a positive impact upon great number of visitors.


By bringing the tropical rainforest directly to the public, the SDBZ is designed to spark visitors’ interest in the role insects play on a global scale. Direct contact with a variety of tropical insects enables visitors to interact with species they otherwise would not have known existed. Contained within the center are a state of the art Live Butterfly Pavilion with over 6,000 square feet of tropical plants and butterflies, a Live Arthropod Lab viewable by the public and utilized for breeding and research programs, and an additional room for offered classes as well as for rental by third parties.


Permitting:

The cost of a USDA annual license is 100USD. Individual permits costs vary from country to country, and are dependent on the number of shipments made.

Foreign export annual permits, depending upon the country, range from 40-200USD.

Equipment procurement:

Butterfly cage costs ~20.00 USD each. With the goal of establishing a community of 60 farmers that puts us at around 1,200 USD.

Assorted equipment, including planting bags, hanging traps, sweep nets, packing supplies, butterfly breeding literature for reference, etc. We estimate this at around 400-700USD.

Access to the community:

Airfare, vehicle rental, local guide. Airfare averages 2,000USD per person to proposed rural communities. It is assumed that two trips will need to be made, one to introduce the idea to the community and confirm the feasibility in the region. And a second trip to bring supplies and set up the co-op. With two team members traveling twice that puts us at around 8,000 USD in airfare alone.

Shipping costs:

Cost of renting and transporting shipment containers with start up materials. This includes all transportation from start to finish.

Examples of shipment costs for one 20’ container from San Diego Port to:

Port Noire, Congo Africa ~8,000 USD

Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea ~5,000 USD


We are estimating our costs at around 20,000 USD to get our first co-op up and running. There are always unexpected costs however so we are setting our funding goal for 25,000 USD in the hopes that we will have the funding to ensure a successful first venture.



Not only are we reaching out through crowd sourcing but we are also semi-finalists in the University of San Diego’s Social Innovation Challenge, a competition like Shark Tank, in which teams of social entrepreneurs compete for mentorship and a portion of $75,000 in seed funding to help make their ventures a reality. The finalists will be announced on April 10th so please stay tuned for that announcement! To make it this far we have worked through hours of business and social analysis and worked with countless social entrepreneur mentors to help develop our idea to a successful level.

You can learn a bit more about our Social Innovation Challenge here!

https://app2.pitchburner.com/s1/pitch?evtid=422336&subid=1017305



April 2015:

Launch website.

Continue permitting process.

Continue facility design and USDA approval for domestic SDBZ center.

Pursue seed funding for international butterfly farming.

May-August 2015:

Pursue partnerships with environmentally focused companies, and social organizations.

Begin domestic pupae breeding and sales to establish customers and increase working capital for international reach.

Begin outreach to possible farming communities.

Winter 2015:

Purchase international farming materials.

Select a foreign farming location to begin our international farming.

Early 2016:

Full time breed domestically and establish foreign farming community, bringing education, supplies, and leadership.

Establish our first co-op community.

Late 2016- 2017:

Establish another co-op community once our first has gained solid footing.

Begin domestic push for entomology (begin permitting process for the SDBZ home facility).

Late 2017:

Grand opening of our home facility offering tropical butterfly pavilion, arthropod displays, classes, and community outreach.

Begin offering classes and cultural education to bring a social impact to all visitors.



A potential problem, as addressed by (Karl Rich, Magda Rich, & Chengappa, 2014), is the difficulty of communicating our positive practices to consumers and investors who can have a large impact on our program and the families we help. When we explain our butterfly focused venture to someone in the entomology community, often the response we receive is immediate and incredibly positive as they understand what it is we are trying to do and who we are helping.

Our biggest difficulty will always be catching the attention of investors or other helpful persons and showing them just how important insects are in our world.

Over the years, Royce has noticed that nowhere is global citizenship better understood than in the entomologic community. As Miriam Rothschild so eloquently puts it, " During the last fifty years, the mildly eccentric web of entomologists has shown us that international co-operation, worldwide, is not only possible and friendly, but agreeable and productive. Between us there are stoutly held views, but no wars, suicide bombers, bayonets or strikes and unfeeling cruelties, only convictions on matters such as classification of butterflies or our affinity with chimpanzees". The San Diego Butterfly Zoo seeks to help people become better global citizens through connectedness and respect for diversity.



The lessons entomology can teach go beyond an appreciation for insect complexity and significance. Entomology can be an all-encompassing tool for global citizenship. Every country is inhabited with insects, and it is that commonality that brings the incredibly diverse group of experts, amateurs, artists, and naturalists close together to promote unity and understanding.

It is often far too evident that United States citizens are disconnected from the rest of our beautifully diverse world. Our mindset is not one of sustainability because we, as a society, are not aware of the countless global communities that support our lavish lifestyle. The SDBZ sees insects as a tool to teach everyone to look at the world around them, and not miss the opportunity to connect with others through a subject that bridges all cultures and mindsets.

Not only are butterflies a sustainable and environmentally friendly source of income, they can also be incredibly profitable. “Gram for gram, exotic butterflies are far more valuable than cattle or, some species even gold”. (Parsons, 1992)

Below image taken from :"The governance of global value chains for live butterflies" by Karl Rich, Magda Rich, and P.G. Chengappa, 2014.



The SDBZ team has a winning combination of determination and ingenuity. Members have experience in public education, business management, and community involvement. The team has the desire and drive to make social change not simply possible, but impactful as well.

Royce Cumming is the president of San Diego State's Men's Crew club team, and a volunteer entomologist at the San Diego Museum of Natural History. Currently serving as an Assistant Scoutmaster for the Boy Scouts of America. Through the Boy Scouts of America, Royce has devoted hundreds of hours to community service. And is proud to have earned the highest rank of Eagle Scout before aging out of the program. He is currently studying management at San Diego State University specializing in entrepreneurship. Over the last eight years he has done various lectures for both children and adults of all ages on a wide variety of entomology topics. He has conducted several presentations to school groups and day care facilities as well as the Children’s Nature Institute in Los Angeles. Regarding his involvement in the entomology community he currently serves as a volunteer entomologist at the NAT and has worked for BioQuip Inc., BicBugs LLC, and the Rhode Island Butterfly Zoo as a breeder and tour guide. He is also a seasonal dried specimen dealer reselling scientific specimens to private collectors or artists that he either collected in the field or obtained from acquaintances.

Mary Beth Bilder is a public health major preparing for her final quarters at UCSD. She is particularly interested in education to enact healthy environmental change. Mary Beth has traveled around the world, and has hundreds of hours of experience working with communities in South America to enact positive environmental change. She travelled to Urubamba, Peru in the summer of 2012 to volunteer for over 400 hours at local clinics. While in the community, she was involved in community education, emphasizing HIV prevention, and promoting awareness of our environment’s impact and importance to health. Her experience in the third world has greatly impacted her worldview and made her infinitely more passionate about improving the lives of those disadvantaged communities. She plans to pursue a Master’s Degree in Public Health, which she hopes to use to better public understanding of the environment’s importance and its impact on our health and well-being. She is passionate about, although new to, the world of entomology and holds a strong belief that greater entomologic awareness will lead to increased ecological conservation worldwide.

Both team members have a passion for travel having collectively visited 15 foreign countries. Global citizenship is a dream of the team.



Besides funding we are always looking for support on social media to help get our word out! Please share this Indiegogo and “Like” us on Facebook @ “San Diego Butterfly Zoo”.

The more people that can see what we are doing and are able to show their support, the closer we get to making our social impact a reality!

https://www.facebook.com/SDButterflyZoo


The San Diego Butterfly Zoo’s mission is to devote itself to nature conservation and to encourage global citizenship through hands on education available to all. By bringing the public closer to the tropical world with state of the art and innovative exhibits, we aim to bridge the gap between the familiar and the exotic. To help bridge that gap and increase our direct environmentalism, the SDBZ will sponsor butterfly farming in the third-world, creating a sustainable income for farmers, reducing the pressure for deforestation.


To facilitate global citizenship, environmentalism, and cultural understanding achieved through the science of entomology, with equal access to all.

Domestically we are establishing a live entomology education and cultural center in San Diego County to increase environmental and cultural awareness. story:
What are Infinity Petbowls?

INFINITY is an ergonomically designed pet bowl for cats and dogs at an affordable price!

From a Puppy or a Kitten to an Adult pet, this specially design tool-less T-Slot system and its matching bowl holders will allow modern dogs and cats to enjoy their food at a convenient height. The Bowl holder can be adjusted from 3” to 8” secured by its aluminum thumb screw. The INFINITY is made of a composite plastic holder and non corrosive aluminum frame. Additionally, it includes removable stainless steel bowls. 


   

San Francisco-based architect and designer EJ Tanu founded DripModule in 2011 to create modern goods that would appeal to people and their pets. Starting in the Bay Area at Tech Shop, he incorporated rapid prototyping methods and used materials primarily sourced from U.S. manufacturers. 

After successfully running a limited production company, he felt it wasn't enough and wanted to create a new product at a new level: A product with even more quality and usability offered at an affordable price. 

People say past experiences are invaluable assets and this proves to be true for Tanu and his company. Efficiency in prototyping and testing has made it possible to create our newest line of pet bowls, Infinity. We have obtained a high demand for it but need funding to start it's production. 

First test cut is using a wood simulation on CNC machine to see if the design and proportion is working, then rough mock-up is developed.

A more detailed mock-up is produced to test it's stability and refine it's materials.

Early Mock-up version

Pre-Production Samples

Full scale models are developed and samples are sent to Pet subjects for their testing. More samples are currently being produced for a broader testing. 


Help us to produce this Ergonomic Pet Bowl design to the market at an affordable price !

The Perks


Q/A

How do I pick the color or size of the Infinity Petbowl?

After the campaign, we’ll reach out to everyone and have you select the color choice as well as the size to match your selection.

Is your Infinity Petbowl not easily tip-over?

Yes, It's very stable and not easily tip over due to position of the pole at "point of gravity" , heavier base and triangulate shape metal base design with anti skid rubber. Position of the Bowls (right on the top of the feet) make the bowls pretty stable when force “down” as well as "side to side". 
We tested with many different types and sized of dogs but so far we do not get any stability problem.

Where did you make the parts and who will assemble Infinity Petbowl ?

Parts of the Infinity bowls are made from various vendors world wide. Majority of the parts and packaging are planned to be made in the USA, Oklahoma City to be precise but some machining parts will be manufactured by our vendors in China.Then all the parts will be collected and assembled in Oklahoma city, USA. All shipping origin will be from USA.

How will you utilized the contribution money from the Indiegogo campaign?

The contribution money as well as the funding that we received from the sale will be used to place a volume order  from our local Oklahoma City vendors and overseas as well as to cover set up fees on assembly line machineries.

When will you start shipping the Infinity?

We are working hard to make the Infinity available as soon as possible. So far we are expecting to start shipping on early April 2016. 

How can you keep the Infinity cost so low?

The price that you received is an introductory discounted price and for a very limited time only. We would like that everybody could afford a nice designed products. This goes back to EJ’s experience. Having had years of experience in design and with in-house manufacturing, we can keep cost low based on volume. Since the design and prototype are done in-house, there is no extra cost to add to the price. We are also working together with our local manufacturer as well as our assembly line to create an efficient production line. 

Can I purchase a wall mounted features? When this will be available?

The wall mounted could be purchased at later date as an accessory. Currently, we are expecting to have it ready for sale by May 2016, the same time as the current release of Infinity floor version.
