story:
Mouseinator is a revolutionary invention that allows the trapping and humane destruction of multiple rodents, eliminating secondary poisoning of native animals and pets as it uses no toxic chemicals to operate. The captured pests are destroyed and contained within the unit for easy disposal reducing the incidence of dead rodents in wall cavities or cupboards etc around the home or farm etc. There is no energy source required and as it operates and resets automatically ...................

Join the MOUSEINATOR movement now and help provide as many units as possible, free of charge to community based groups !!!


About the project -

My name is Daryl and I grew up in Country Victoria where I spent my childhood years planning adventures that involved plenty of mechanical things to maintain and repair such as motorbikes and motor vehicles etc.

My family always had an inventive and resourceful nature which I believe has led me to be able to develop this new creation, the Mouseinator. I have been working on this product for several years testing and developing many different prototypes at different stages to achieve this latest product design.

Contributors to this project will help bring about a chemical free alternative to the mass capture and control of mouse numbers without unnecessary suffering of the mice or possible secondary poisoning or suffering to native animals or pets. The potential cost savings and drop in the use of material resources due to its use is of considerable significance.

Following their arrival in Australia, introduced rodents have posed detrimental impacts on native Australian fauna. Native marsupials and rodents such as the Antechinus and New Holland Mouse have become diminished in population size and have experienced a contracted distribution as a result of the increased competition with the house mouse. According to the Australian Government Canberra in their 1995 publication Action Plan for Australian Rodents "rodents account for half of Australia's mammal extinction since European settlement" indicating the dire situation of our native species whose survival is further jeopardised by the continued use of toxic baiting. On islands where house mice have been introduced, seabird colonies are often effected as their eggs (and sometimes chicks) are eaten by the mice. Secondary poisoning of birds, particularly raptors but also Magpie, Butcherbirds, Curlews and Kookaburra is a significant concern. Bird-keepers are also detrimented by problematic rodents which spoil seed, feast on eggs and attract snakes to their aviaries. During Rodent plagues well known native predators such as the Kite, Kestrel, Falcon and Hobby species will congregate and feed almost exclusively off mice as they are easy prey in such numbers, as a result of this many raptor unwittingly ingest baited mice and hence succumb to the same fate as their prey. During these times it is not uncommon for wildlife carers to witness raptors and the like being regularly bought in and dying from ingesting baited mice. Reptiles are additionally known to suffer from ingesting poisoned baits or poisoned animals as many of the current poisonous baits appear to be target specific and hence may be taken by wildlife, livestock and pets.

A Kookaburra eating a mouse. Photo by Ian Montgommery



Professional pest controller Daniel Watt who has over 20 years experience dealing with pests talks about MOUSEINATOR 


HOW IT WORKS -

The Mouseinator uses an enclosed non toxic baited area that has a teetering trap door arrangement secured and triggered by a magnetic catch or locking device. The mouse enters the feeding area through a small hole in the far end of the device and immediately steps onto the end of the locked teetering platform applying a downward force onto the magnetic catch and housing securing the platform. This ensures no sensation of movement is felt by the mouse. The mouse then feels safe and travels along the platform until it reaches the pivot point that has low friction axis to aid the swift operation of the impending trapdoor effect. Past this point the pressure applied to the magnetic catch end of the device changes to an upward force that will eventually release the catch when the leverage force becomes great enough. The force increases as the mass of the mouse moves along the platform towards the bait station until it releases in a sudden movement. The mouse at this position on the platform when the magnetic catch releases, ensures the force of its own weight drops the platform rapidly from underneath with no chance of escape. The Platform is designed so that various sizes and weight of mice release the catch at different lengths across the platform as the leverage applied to the catch is enough to initiate the release. The mouse then falls into a capturing cavity area below the platform that is filled with vegetable oil (usually discarded cooking oil) where it is captured and very quickly drowned. At the point in which the mouse slides off the platform the weight is shifted slightly biased towards the platforms original position so it returns to be locked by the magnetic catch again. The trap is now automatically set again for the next mouse. The specific gravity or relative density of the vegetable oil is such that the mouse sinks quickly and is humanely destroyed. This dramatically reduces the suffering of the mice as traditional poisoning can take 7 -10 days to eventually exterminate a pest, a long drawn out suffering of the animal that can even take longer if only a small amount of poison is consumed. The Mouseinator can hold the captured dead rodents for extended periods of time due to the preserving effect of the oil. I have also researched and developed a totally natural stabilizer to extend the ability to preserve the captured rodents for many months. This makes it ideal to use in a holiday home pantry or situations where the trap may not be checked on a regular basis. I actually have mice that were captured several years ago in oil with my additive that gives off no noticeable offensive odour.

 

Cost effective properties of this device is extremely impressive as one of my prototypes has captured more than a thousand mice and is several years old. It has no working parts that would conceivably wear out in perhaps up to a several years of use. It could conceivably capture tens of thousands of pests and still keep going. Compared to chemical baiting that has much wastage and often non specific targeting of pest animals etc, this device offers incredible value for pest suffering reduction , environmental issues such as secondary poisoning of native species and pets, chemical reduction in the food chain etc and real value for money for the consumer that purchases the item.




What I need to bring this product to market & What perks are available -

I am seeking $80,000  to finish off CAD drawings, finalise design work, and to manufacture complicated industrial dyes for plastic injection moulds to get this product to the market place.

I am offering perks of early orders of the device at a special introductory price of $60.00 USD.

Postage is not included yet as costs are still being calculated and will be added at a later date before the campaign ends after the best deal from freight companies has been organised.

Delivery is estimated to be April 2016.

In the event I don't reach my campaign goal I will use whatever funds raised to continue on with the project. I intend to follow through with getting this product to market.

A Nankeen Kestrel feeding young in a nesting hollow.  Photo by John Cooper


The Impact -

The Mouseinator is aimed at reducing the suffering of native animals and mice due to the reduction of poisonous baiting. It is also designed to reduce toxic chemical use in the food chain. Native animals and pets should be further protected by the elimination of secondary poisoning with this device. This should impact on the environment in a positive way as well give an optimistic outlook that as individuals we can make a positive contribution to the world our future generations will inherit.

I have no track record in this particular area however I believe that it is my fresh approach to design and researching the mice behaviour through infra red video etc has been my strength in design, development and investigation of a better way to humanely dispose of rodents. I plan to further surround myself with a capable individuals throughout the business growth to succeed in the market place. Any contributor to this project can be assured that they are joining forces with an environmentally friendly business.

I have been unable to raise enough funds to complete this project so far. I am now hoping the power of collective  individuals can make a difference to the reduction of suffering of animals and reduction of chemical use in the environment we live in.

If I am lucky enough to reach my campaign goal,  any contributed funds (excluding perks) over the target amount would be used directly towards providing as many devices as possible, as a gift, to non profit community based groups. This would be done on behalf of all my campaign contributors.

Worthy recipients such as volunteer fire fighting organisations, surf rescue and life saving clubs, scouts and guide groups, Senior citizens clubs and organisations, Country Women's and Men's Groups, Town Hall Committees etc, would be offered these devices to show our appreciation for their support given to the community.

Risks & Challenges with the Project -

There is of course a risk that I may fail with this project.

Having said that I have spent many years of hard work researching and developing this product and the most difficult obstacles are behind me. I have managed any risks and challenges I have had so far and I calculate and consider things carefully before acting on them. As the product develops I will seek assistance from talented individuals to produce and promote the product in the market place.


WHY SUPPORT THIS PRODUCT -

Mice can cause considerable damage to the environment and with the toxic methods currently being used to control their numbers there is risk to secondary poisoning of native species and pets as well as toxic substances being introduced into the food chain. These methods are also not particularly humane and do not reflect most community expectations of how animals should be treated during control of their numbers by human intervention.

According to a University of Nebraska publication for the United States Department of Agriculture Wildlife Research Centre by Gary Witmer and William Pitt "Invasive Rodents in the United States'-

"House mice are native to southern Europe, northern Africa  and Asia. They now occur worldwide, including Antarctica, and are probably the most numerous and widespread mammalian species in the world next to humans. While house mice originated in the grasslands of Central Asia, they have followed humans around the world as stowaways on ships. They are very good invaders and probably reached to most parts of the world as stowaways on ships and cargo. House mice have remarkable abilities that have allowed them to be highly successful in many habitats around the world. Chief among these are their reproductive potential and their adaptability in different environments.

House mice are small, slender rodents with fur that is grayish brown above and gray to buff underneath. This  small (maximum mass of about 20 g for adults) and highly prolific animal is a  continuous breeder in many situations; a female can produce 5-10 litters, each with 5-6 young, per year. The young mature within about 3 weeks and soon become reproductively active. House mice are short-lived (generally less than one year) and have high population tum-over. In one study, 20 mice placed in an outdoor enclosure with abundant food,  water, and cover, became a population of 2,000 in eight months.

House mice have amazing abilities which allow them to access almost any available areas or resources.

House mice cause many types of damage. A major concern is the consumption and contamination of stored foods; it has been estimated that substantial amounts of stored foods are lost each year in this manner. Mice also consume and contaminate large amounts of livestock feed at animal production facilities. While mice generally live in close proximity to humans, sometimes feral populations occur. In these cases, the mice may damage many types of crops in the field, especially com, cereal grains, and legun1es. Australia has mouse "plagues" periodically resulting in enormous losses to stored crops and crops in the field. In buildings, a mouse infestation can be a considerable nuisance because of the noise, odours, and droppings. More imp01tantly, they damage insulation and wiring. House fires  have been caused by mice gnawing electrical wires; likewise,  communication systems have been shut down  for  periods of time resulting in economic losses. Additionally,  house mice are susceptible to a large number of disease agents and endo-parasites.

Consequently, they serve as  reservoirs  and vectors of disease transmission to humans, pets, and livestock. lmportant among these  diseases  are leptospirosis, plague,  salmonella,  lymphocytic choriomeningitis, and toxoplasmosis. Finally,  when introduced to islands, mice can cause significant damage to natural resources, including both flora and fauna. For example, on Gough Island and, mice fed on nestling albatross chicks . Additionally, Witmer (unpubl. data) documented seedling damage by house mice in a pen study. However, mice are subordinate to introduced rats so the impacts of mice not noticed when  rats  are  also  present  on  the  island .  This phenomenon  was demonstrated by the large increase in mice abundance on Buck Island, USVI, after invasive roof rats were eradicated.

A large number of  methods and materials  have been developed to  help solve  house mouse problems. In general, the use of multiple approaches and materials - integrated pest management- is more likely to reduce a mouse problem to a tolerable level . The  tools available and their proper use  have been extensively reviewed (Brooks,  1973; Prakash, 1988; Timm, 1994b; Corrigan, 2001).

Rodenticides are widely used in the United States as well other parts of the world. Both primary (direct consumption) and secondary hazards (consuming a poisoned rodent or poisoned non-target animal) can occur to non-target animals when rodenticides are used.

Rodenticides such as brodifacoum (a second generation anticoagulant) are highly toxic, but also result in persistent residues in body tissues of animals that consume poisoned rodents

There is a growing concern about the secondary effects of these residues in predatory animals (e.g. , Thomas et aI. , 2011).

Additional research is needed to improve existing methods and to develop new methods for invasive rodent detection and control. More research is needed in both lethal and nonlethal means of resolving rodent damage situations.

A number of challenges remain with invasive rodent management and eradication in the United States. Some of the challenges faced include the public and agency concerns about the use of toxicants and traps, land access (especially to private lands), public attitudes, resource availability, and detection and monitoring difficulties. Nonetheless,  we  will  hopefully  continue  to  relieve  the  burdens  on  insular  and mainland ec.osystems caused by rodent introductions. The flora and fauna of islands generally respond favourably and rapidly after invasive rodents are removed. Endemic. threatened, or endangered species can be, and have been, re-introduced after successful rodent eradications. For  example,  the endangered St.  Croix  ground lizard  (Ameiva  polops) was  recently re­ introduced to Buck Island in the U.S. Virgin Islands after the successful eradication of roof rats. The recent eradication of Polynesian rats and house mice from Cocos Island (a small island off of Guam) set the stage for the re-introduction of the endangered Guam rail (flightless bird species).

Invasive  rodents  will  continue  to  pose  challenges  to  land  and  resource managers, commodity  producers,  and  homeowners.  Many  tools  are  available  to  reduce  rodent populations and associated damage. They should be used in a well thought out IPM approach.

Additionally,  seabird  populations,  sea  turtle  populations  and  other  island  resources warrant protection from invasive rodents. The recovery of fauna and flora on uninhabited islands  after a successful  rodent eradication is particularly notable. The significant impacts of introduced rodents on native flora and fauna have been repeatedly demonstrated. Invasive rodents are very adaptable, can exploit a wide array of resources as food and cover, and can increase reproduction very quickly when and where  abundant  resources  exist.  While  invasive  rodents will continue to pose challenges to land and resource managers, they can be controlled or even eradicated with a well-planned and adequately-supported effort using rodenticides and other tools. With proper planning, non-target losses  will be 1ninimal and these populations, along with other island resources, will often recover quickly after the invasive rodents have been removed." 

- QUOTED FROM SOURCE "Invasive Rodents in the United States'

Other Ways You Can Help -

I realise that many of you may not be in a position financially to help with this project. If you could just let as many friends as you can know about my product that would be a great help and very much appreciated. You can use the share tools to get this project heading in the right direction.

DISCLAIMER -

"Delivery of rewards or perks are subject to best efforts and not guaranteed"

I have been informed PayPal requires the above disclaimer to be displayed on the page...

Please note that I am very confident of being able to deliver the products in the time frame allocated.

Thanks for your interest and support.

Daryl Pinder.
story_txt:
Mouseinator is a revolutionary invention that
allows the trapping and humane destruction of multiple rodents, eliminating
secondary poisoning of native animals and pets as it uses no toxic chemicals to
operate. The captured pests are destroyed and contained within the unit for
easy disposal reducing the incidence of dead rodents in wall cavities or
cupboards etc around the home or farm etc. There is no energy source required
and as it operates and resets automatically ................... Join the MOUSEINATOR movement now and help provide as many units as
possible, free of charge to community based groups !!!About the project -
My name is Daryl and I grew up in Country Victoria where I spent my
childhood years planning adventures that involved plenty of mechanical things
to maintain and repair such as motorbikes and motor vehicles etc.
My family always had an inventive and resourceful nature which I believe
has led me to be able to develop this new creation, the Mouseinator. I have been
working on this product for several years testing and developing many different
prototypes at different stages to achieve this latest product design.
Contributors to this project will help bring about a chemical free alternative
to the mass capture and control of mouse numbers without unnecessary suffering
of the mice or possible secondary poisoning or suffering to native animals or
pets. The potential cost savings and drop in the use of material resources due
to its use is of considerable significance.
Following their arrival in Australia, introduced rodents have posed
detrimental impacts on native Australian fauna. Native marsupials and rodents
such as the Antechinus and New Holland Mouse have become diminished in
population size and have experienced a contracted distribution as a result of
the increased competition with the house mouse. According to the Australian
Government Canberra in their 1995 publication Action Plan for Australian
Rodents "rodents account for half of Australia's mammal extinction since
European settlement" indicating the dire situation of our native species
whose survival is further jeopardised by the continued use of toxic baiting. On
islands where house mice have been introduced, seabird colonies are often
effected as their eggs (and sometimes chicks) are eaten by the mice. Secondary
poisoning of birds, particularly raptors but also Magpie, Butcherbirds, Curlews
and Kookaburra is a significant concern. Bird-keepers are also detrimented by
problematic rodents which spoil seed, feast on eggs and attract snakes to their
aviaries. During Rodent plagues well known native predators such as the Kite,
Kestrel, Falcon and Hobby species will congregate and feed almost exclusively
off mice as they are easy prey in such numbers, as a result of this many raptor
unwittingly ingest baited mice and hence succumb to the same fate as their
prey. During these times it is not uncommon for wildlife carers to witness
raptors and the like being regularly bought in and dying from ingesting baited
mice. Reptiles are additionally known to suffer from ingesting poisoned baits
or poisoned animals as many of the current poisonous baits appear to be target
specific and hence may be taken by wildlife, livestock and pets.







A Kookaburra eating a mouse.
Photo by Ian Montgommery


Professional pest controller Daniel Watt who has over 20 years experience dealing with pests talks about MOUSEINATOR HOW IT WORKS -
The Mouseinator uses an enclosed non
toxic baited area that has a teetering trap door arrangement secured and
triggered by a magnetic catch or locking device. The mouse enters the feeding
area through a small hole in the far end of the device and immediately steps
onto the end of the locked teetering platform applying a downward force onto
the magnetic catch and housing securing the platform. This ensures no sensation
of movement is felt by the mouse. The mouse then feels safe and travels along
the platform until it reaches the pivot point that has low friction axis to aid the swift operation of the
impending trapdoor effect. Past this point the pressure applied to the magnetic
catch end of the device changes to an upward force that will eventually release
the catch when the leverage force becomes great enough. The force increases as
the mass of the mouse moves along the platform towards the bait station until
it releases in a sudden movement. The mouse at this position on the platform
when the magnetic catch releases, ensures the force of its own weight drops the
platform rapidly from underneath with no chance of escape. The Platform is
designed so that various sizes and weight of mice release the catch at
different lengths across the platform as the leverage applied to the catch is
enough to initiate the release. The mouse then falls into a capturing cavity
area below the platform that is filled with vegetable oil (usually discarded
cooking oil) where it is captured and very quickly drowned. At the point in
which the mouse slides off the platform the weight is shifted slightly biased
towards the platforms original position so it returns to be locked by the
magnetic catch again. The trap is now automatically set again for the next
mouse. The specific gravity or relative density of the vegetable oil is such
that the mouse sinks quickly and is humanely destroyed. This dramatically
reduces the suffering of the mice as traditional poisoning can take 7 -10 days
to eventually exterminate a pest, a long drawn out suffering of the animal that
can even take longer if only a small amount of poison is consumed. The
Mouseinator can hold the captured dead rodents for extended periods of time due
to the preserving effect of the oil. I have also researched and developed a
totally natural stabilizer to extend the ability to preserve the captured
rodents for many months. This makes it ideal to use in a holiday home pantry or
situations where the trap may not be checked on a regular basis. I actually
have mice that were captured several years ago in oil with my additive that gives
off no noticeable offensive odour.
 


Cost effective properties of this device
is extremely impressive as one of my prototypes has captured more than a
thousand mice and is several years old. It has no working parts that would
conceivably wear out in perhaps up to a several years of use. It could
conceivably capture tens of thousands of pests and still keep going. Compared
to chemical baiting that has much wastage and often non specific targeting of
pest animals etc, this device offers incredible value for pest suffering
reduction , environmental issues such as secondary poisoning of native species
and pets, chemical reduction in the food chain etc and real value for money for
the consumer that purchases the item.



What I need to bring this product to
market & What perks are available -
I am seeking $80,000  to finish off CAD drawings, finalise design work, and to manufacture
complicated industrial dyes for plastic injection moulds to get this product to the
market place.
I am offering perks of early orders of the device at a special
introductory price of $60.00 USD. 
Postage is not included yet as costs are still being calculated and will
be added at a later date before the campaign ends after the best deal from
freight companies has been organised.
Delivery is estimated to be April 2016.
In the event I don't reach my campaign goal I will use whatever funds
raised to continue on with the project. I intend to follow through with getting
this product to market. 






A Nankeen Kestrel feeding young in a
nesting hollow.  Photo by John Cooper

The Impact -
The Mouseinator is aimed at reducing the suffering of native animals and
mice due to the reduction of poisonous baiting. It is also designed to reduce
toxic chemical use in the food chain. Native animals and pets should be further
protected by the elimination of secondary poisoning with this device. This
should impact on the environment in a positive way as well give an optimistic
outlook that as individuals we can make a positive contribution to the world
our future generations will inherit. 
I have no track record in this particular area however I believe that it
is my fresh approach to design and researching the mice behaviour through infra
red video etc has been my strength in design, development and investigation of
a better way to humanely dispose of rodents. I plan to further surround myself
with a capable individuals throughout the business growth to succeed in the
market place. Any contributor to this project can be assured that they are
joining forces with an environmentally friendly business.
I have been unable to raise enough funds to complete this
project so far. I am now hoping the power of collective  individuals can
make a difference to the reduction of suffering of animals and reduction of
chemical use in the environment we live in.
If I am lucky enough to reach my
campaign goal,  any contributed funds
(excluding perks) over the target amount would be used directly towards providing
as many devices as possible, as a gift, to non profit community based groups.
This would be done on behalf of all my campaign contributors.
Worthy recipients such as volunteer fire
fighting organisations, surf rescue and life saving clubs, scouts and guide
groups, Senior citizens clubs and organisations, Country Women's and Men's
Groups, Town Hall Committees etc, would be offered these devices to show our
appreciation for their support given to the community.
Risks & Challenges with the Project
-
There is of course a risk that I may fail with this project.
Having said that I have spent many years of hard work researching and developing this product and the most difficult obstacles are behind me. I have managed any risks and challenges I have had so far and I calculate and consider things carefully before acting on them. As the product develops I will seek assistance from talented individuals to produce and promote the product in the market place.

story:
Intro

As part of our mission here at The National Reptile Zoo, we want to continue to inspire a passion for nature in our visitors and encourage them to become more engaged with the natural world around them. 

For the past decade, our existing Tropical Walk-through Exhibit has engaged and fascinated members of the public as they interact with our free roaming lizards and tortoise. Visitors walk away from this exhibit with a new found respect and appreciation for the animal world, and with a better understanding of the conservation of our environment.

But after ten years, its time to re-build and make it bigger! This is where you come in...

Unfortunately for us conservation is not free, we receive no funding from any government body and it is through your generosity and interest that we have been able to continue, we need your help in funding a new dome exhibit, giving our scaly friends a fantastic new habitat, flooded with natural light, filled with live tropical plants, and three times the size of their existing home!

Not only that, but you're also helping to educate future generations about the plight of endangered species in the wild, helping to conserve what we love.

What We Need & What You Get

We have started construction of a Geodesic Dome, created with sustainable timber which will be covered in transparent polycarbonate. This polycarbonate allows penetration of essential UV rays which up to now, we have been providing by way of artificial light. Without these rays, reptiles cannot metabolise calcium in their system, eventually leading to death. 

Within this dome, we will recreate a tropical rain forest, complete with misting system (recreating natural rainfall), supplementary heating system, and bio-active forest floor. Just what every reptile wants to make them feel at home!

Of course, we want you to enjoy this exhibit too, along with the rest of the zoo! That's why we're going to give our contributors a little something back. Anyone contributing over €200 will receive a years family membership. If you contribute over €500, we will give you ten years membership! And if you're a major contributor, we'll give you VIP lifetime membership!!

Other Ways You Can Help

Sometimes people just don't have the funds to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help;

Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Link us on Facebook, Tweet about the campaign, tell everybody!

And don't forget to use  Indiegogo share tools to spread the word.

Now lets build an amazing habitat!

story:
AIDEZ-NOUS À SAUVEZ LES FRÊNES DE MONTRÉAL

Mise en situation

L’agrile du frêne est un insecte ravageur exotique originaire d’Asie du Sud-Est s'attaquant aux frênes, des arbres feuillus communs à la région des grands lacs et abondamment retrouvés dans les villes. Cet insecte a été vu pour la première fois au Canada en 2002. Depuis, il ne cesse de se reproduire et de se répandre, détruisant notre belle biodiversité sur son passage. Un frêne infecté à plus de 30% n’a plus aucune chance de survie. Il doit malheureusement être abattu. À Montréal, plus de 200 000 frênes publics sont menacés d’être détruits par l’agrile. Ce nombre ne compte pas ceux des terrains privés et ceux des grands parcs métropolitains. Il faut donc passer rapidement à l’action afin d’éviter la perte de ces majestueux feuillus.

Notre organisme : Les Pousses urbaines 

Nous sommes un organisme d'économie social spécialisé en agriculture et en horticulture responsable. Depuis 2014, nous sommes également certifiés pour traiter les frênes contre l'agrile avec le produit TreeAzin. Il s'agit d'un insecticide naturel mis au point par Ressources naturelles Canada en collaboration avec BioForest Technologies Inc. Nous sommes touchés par ce fléau et nous désirons lutter afin de protéger les frênes.

 (https://www.rncan.gc.ca/science/article/11703)

Description de notre projet

Nous avons besoin de votre appui pour sauver les frênes.

Avec votre collaboration, nous désirons amasser des fonds afin de protéger le plus grand nombre de frênes possible à Montréal. 

IL COÛTE EN MOYENNE 300$ POUR TRAITER 1 SEUL FRÊNE MATURE. Cela-dit, si chacun apporte sa contribution, nous serons certainement en mesure d’atteindre notre OBJECTIF DE 3000$ POUR TRAITER 10 ARBRES. Si nous récoltons davantage, plus de frênes seront protégés et ce sont tous les citoyens qui en bénéficieront.

Pourquoi voudriez-vous sauver les arbres

Les arbres sont essentiels à notre environnement urbain. En effet, producteurs du phénomène de photosynthèse, ils créent de l’oxygène qui purifie l’air. Leurs feuilles captent également la poussière et les polluants, ce qui améliore grandement notre milieu de vie. De plus, les racines des arbres sont d’excellents stabilisateurs du sol et réduisent fortement son érosion, notamment dans les rues en pente. Les arbres sont aussi un protecteur naturel contre les ilots de chaleur et réduisent considérablement la vitesse du vent. Sans compter qu’ils procurent une valeur ajoutée indéniable dans le plaisir d’habiter le quartier !

Afin de connaitre tous les avantages des végétaux, nous vous invitons à consulter le site internet suivant : www.arboquebec.com/importance

Étant citoyens d’une grande ville, les arbres contribuent à notre qualité de vie. Nous avons la chance de posséder un nombre important de frênes matures sur notre territoire. Mobilisons-nous pour les protéger et éviter leur abattage, car même s’ils sont remplacés par de jeunes arbres d’un à deux mètres, cela prendra des années avant de retrouver le couvert de feuilles offert par des frênes matures.

Comment pouvez-vous sauver les arbres

Que vous soyez locataires, propriétaires, citoyens de la ville de Montréal ou non, vous pouvez tous contribuer à cette campagne. En choisissant le montant de votre contribution, vous recevrez un ou plusieurs choix de semences et même des pousses de fines herbes et fleurs.  

Notre campagne Indiegogo durera un mois, suite à quoi nous passerons immédiatement à l'action et vous ferons un suivi des arbres traités. Suite à cette première campagne de financement, vous pourrez continuer d'appuyer le projet tout au long de l'année via notre site web afin de poursuivre le traitement des frênes lors de la saison estivale de 2016. De plus amples informations sur la deuxième phase de financement seront transmises sur notre site internet et notre page facebook. 

http://www.poussesurbaines.org/

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Les-Pousses-Urbaines/114580838670687?fref=ts

Les Pousses urbaines vous remercient à l’avance de votre appui. N’hésitez pas à passer le mot auprès de vos proches, les frênes sont l’affaire de tous !

***

Context

The emerald ash borer is an exotic insect pest native to Southeast Asia that attacks the ash trees, common hardwood of the Great Lakes region and abundantly found in cities. This insect was seen for the first time in Canada in 2002. Since then, it continues to reproduce and spread, destroying our beautiful biodiversity in its path. An ash infected more than 30% has no chance of survival. It must unfortunately be cut down. In Montreal, more than 200 000 public ash trees are in danger of being destroyed by the emerald ash borer. This number does not count those in private lands and those of the great metropolitan parks. We must act quickly to prevent the loss of these majestic hardwoods.

Our organization: Les Pousses urbaines

We are a social economy organization specialized in agriculture and responsible urban horticulture. Since 2014 we also are certified to treat ash trees against the emerald ash borer with the product TreeAzin. It is a natural insecticide developed by Ressources Naturelles Canada and BioForest Technologies Inc. We are affected by this scourge and we want to fight to protect ash tress in our neighborhood.

 (https://www.rncan.gc.ca/science/article/11703)

Description of our project

We need your support to save the ash trees within public spaces and parks in Montreal. Districts are responsible for taking care of ash trees located on the edge of the sidewalks. Owners will be responsible for the trees on their land. In terms of public spaces like parks, ash trees are unfortunately left to themselves.

That's where you come in. With your cooperation, we want to raise funds to protect the greatest number of ash trees located in this park, which is a green area popular and frequented by citizens.

We must pay an amount of $ 300 TO IMMUNIZE ONE ASH TREE.If everyone contributes, we will be able to achieve our goal of $ 3,000 TO TREAT 10 TREES. If we collect more, then more ash trees will be protected and these will benefit all citizens. 

Why would you save trees

Trees are vital to our urban environment. Indeed, producers of photosynthesis, they create oxygen which purifies the air. Their leaves also capture dust and pollutants, which greatly improves our environment. In addition, tree’s roots are excellent soil stabilizers significantly reducing soil erosion, especially in steep roads. They also help regulate the heat island effect, which prevails in Montreal during summer, and considerably reduce wind speed. Besides, they add value by enhancing the pleasure of living in the neighborhood!

To learn more about all the benefits provided by plants, please visit this website: www.arboquebec.com/importance

As citizens of a great city, trees contribute to our life quality. We are fortunate to have a large number of mature ash trees on our territory. Let’s mobilize to protect them and avoid their slaughter, because even if young trees replace them, it will take years before returning to the great canopy offered by mature ash trees.

How can you save the trees

Whether you are tenants, owners, neighborhood residents of Montreal or not, you can all contribute to our funding campaign via Indiegogo web platform. By choosing the amount of your contribution, you will receive one or more choices of seeds and/or herbs. 

Our Indiegogo campaign will last a month, after which we'll immediately take action and, of course, keep you informed about the treated trees. Following this first fundraiser, the population will be able to continue to support the project throughout the year via the PayPal site in order for us to pursue the treatment of ash trees in the summer of 2016. Further information about the second funding phase will be transmitted on our website and our facebook page.

http://www.poussesurbaines.org/

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Les-Pousses-Urbaines/114580838670687?fref=ts

Les Pousses urbaines thank you in advance for your support!
story_txt:
AIDEZ-NOUS À SAUVEZ LES FRÊNES DE MONTRÉALMise en situation
L’agrile
du frêne est un insecte ravageur exotique originaire d’Asie du Sud-Est s'attaquant aux frênes, des arbres feuillus communs à la région des grands lacs et abondamment retrouvés dans les villes. Cet insecte a été vu pour la première fois au Canada en
2002. Depuis, il ne cesse de se reproduire et de se répandre, détruisant notre
belle biodiversité sur son passage. Un frêne infecté à plus de 30% n’a plus
aucune chance de survie. Il doit malheureusement être abattu. À Montréal, plus de 200 000 frênes publics sont menacés d’être détruits par l’agrile. Ce nombre ne compte pas ceux des terrains privés et ceux des grands parcs métropolitains. Il faut donc
passer rapidement à l’action afin d’éviter la perte de ces majestueux feuillus.


Notre organisme : Les Pousses urbaines Nous sommes un organisme d'économie social spécialisé en agriculture et en horticulture responsable. Depuis 2014, nous sommes également certifiés pour traiter les frênes contre l'agrile avec le produit TreeAzin. Il s'agit d'un insecticide naturel mis au point par Ressources naturelles Canada en collaboration avec BioForest Technologies Inc. Nous sommes touchés par ce fléau et nous désirons lutter afin de protéger les frênes. (https://www.rncan.gc.ca/science/article/11703)




Description de notre projet 
Nous
avons besoin de votre appui pour sauver les frênes. 
Avec
votre collaboration, nous désirons amasser des fonds afin de protéger le plus
grand nombre de frênes possible à Montréal. 

IL COÛTE EN MOYENNE 300$ POUR TRAITER 1 SEUL FRÊNE MATURE. Cela-dit, si chacun apporte sa
contribution, nous serons certainement en mesure d’atteindre notre OBJECTIF DE 3000$ POUR TRAITER 10 ARBRES. Si nous récoltons davantage, plus de
frênes seront protégés et ce sont tous les citoyens qui en bénéficieront.



Pourquoi voudriez-vous sauver les arbres
Les
arbres sont essentiels à notre environnement urbain. En effet, producteurs du
phénomène de photosynthèse, ils créent de l’oxygène qui purifie l’air. Leurs
feuilles captent également la poussière et les polluants, ce qui améliore
grandement notre milieu de vie. De plus, les racines des arbres sont d’excellents
stabilisateurs du sol et réduisent fortement son érosion, notamment dans les
rues en pente. Les arbres sont aussi un protecteur naturel contre les ilots de
chaleur et réduisent considérablement la vitesse du vent. Sans compter qu’ils procurent
une valeur ajoutée indéniable dans le plaisir d’habiter le quartier !
Afin de
connaitre tous les avantages des végétaux, nous vous invitons à consulter le
site internet suivant : www.arboquebec.com/importance
Étant
citoyens d’une grande ville, les arbres contribuent à notre qualité de vie. Nous
avons la chance de posséder un nombre important de frênes matures sur notre
territoire. Mobilisons-nous pour les protéger et éviter leur abattage, car même
s’ils sont remplacés par de jeunes arbres d’un à deux mètres, cela prendra des
années avant de retrouver le couvert de feuilles offert par des frênes matures.
Comment pouvez-vous sauver les arbres



Que vous soyez locataires, propriétaires, citoyens de la ville de Montréal ou non, vous pouvez tous contribuer à cette campagne. En choisissant le montant de votre contribution, vous recevrez un ou plusieurs choix de semences et même des pousses de fines herbes et fleurs.  
Notre campagne Indiegogo durera un mois, suite à quoi nous passerons immédiatement à l'action et vous ferons un suivi des arbres traités. Suite à cette première campagne de financement, vous pourrez continuer d'appuyer le projet tout au long de l'année via notre site web afin de poursuivre le traitement des frênes lors de la saison estivale de 2016. De plus amples informations sur la deuxième phase de financement seront transmises sur notre site internet et notre page facebook. http://www.poussesurbaines.org/https://www.facebook.com/pages/Les-Pousses-Urbaines/114580838670687?fref=ts

Les
Pousses urbaines vous remercient à l’avance de votre appui. N’hésitez pas à
passer le mot auprès de vos proches, les frênes sont l’affaire de tous !***Context
