story:
Short Summary

Janas Ecovillage is a collective of people working together in order to build and bring to life a non-formal educational centre for sustainability. We are located in Janas, in the beautiful landscapes of the UNESCO Sintra World Heritage site. We have been working actively since 2012 in building this centre, applying and sharing practical and innovative solutions towards greater resilience at the local and regional level. 

The aims of this initiative are based on practical skills and experiences and learning by doing in the various areas of sustainability that are necessary to reach a more balanced eco-social system. We have building a network of collaborators, students, trainers and residents through diverse activities, local services and products: agroforestry, nurseries and seed banks, regenerative agriculture, natural beekeeping, handicrafts, carpentry and natural building, ecological restoration, environmental consultancy and design, education and course teachings, local products (canned fruit and veg, homemade beer, cider and mushrooms).

The focus and work in landscape recovery (soil, plant and animal biodiversity) was from the beginning one of the main areas of intervention in Janas Ecovillage. 

After four years of this active restoration work our landscape is a living example and case study of an effective ecological succession with an increase in biodiversity and productivity (biomass, vegetation, food, forage, soil quality, animals, bees, water retention and availability, etc).

Throughout this time of working towards the vision for an educational and training centre, we have become skilled in diverse techniques of plant propagation (seeds, herbaceous plants, shrubs and trees) and shared this knowledge with collaborators, teachers and students. We have built a small local agroforestry nursery to sustain our vision and active work in ecological restoration. With that we were also able to support other local and regional initiatives with similar objectives and the need for a biodiverse range of quality plants and trees to serve various ecological functions. At the moment we have more than four thousand tree and shrub plants in our original nursery and predict to reach twenty thousand these current year. 

Now is the right moment to make a big leap, to share our experience, knowledge and skills and have a bigger impactin ecological restoration at the local, regional and also national level, with the building and establishment of a larger forest-tree nursery.

Our main objective is to create a large nursery to produce trees, shrubs and perennial plant species, in three main areas of action and research: 


(i) research, recovery, propagation and conservation of native and traditional plant and tree varieties (naturally adapted to the climatic and biotic conditions of Portugal)

(ii) research, propagation, conservation and introduction of trees and plants adapted to Mediterranean climates with high potential and diverse ecological functions for agroforestry and ecosystem restoration.

(iii) research, recovery, propagation and conservation of traditional fruit tree varieties for human food products (naturally adapted to the climatic and biotic conditions of Portugal)


What We Need and What You Can Get

To set our project on stable feet from the beginning we will need a total amount of 4,900 euros (5,600 US dollars). This fundraising campaign aims to obtain the minimum amount considered essential for the start-up and first investment, in a initiative that intends to produce more than 20,000 trees in the second year.



Of this ideal fundraising budget, the amount will be divided and flow into three main areas of construction and implementation:

(i) an 80 square metre nursery of wood and glass with plant propagation benches. TheJanas Ecovillage team will support all the technical construction works. 

(ii) a biomass burner as a heater for winter temperature regulation, which is very important to maintain the biotic and abiotic conditions for the preservation and maintenance of nursery plants (mainly for the endangered species and the new rare varieties, reducing the probability of losses).

(iii) an aquaponics system that will assure a combined and closed system for providing fertility to the plants, assuring nutrient supply, increasing productivity and reducing waste through reuse of by-products.

All the budget is calculated to support the minimum amount that we need to create this tree nursery. If we don't reach our entire goal we will get started with the wooden nursery and benches to propagate our trees, plants and seeds.

What you can get is closely related to the impact of the initiative (see next section) which among other possibilities, includes the following: you will be able to visit, learn and practise how to install and maintain a nursery structure combined with three systems (propagation benches, biomass burner and aquaponics), to have access to a biodiverse range of plants and seeds with various functions, to receive our technical support with ecological restoration and agroforestry design, and to support a project that acts directly as a carbon sink through the important role that trees play.

The funding campaing perks is divided by the amount of plant or seed diversity you can get to implement your agroforestry project (first or advanced steps). You can get seeds, tubers, plants, fruit trees and agroforestry indicated trees. You will be able to participate in agroforestry trainnings in Janas Ecovillage and also certificates as you will be one of the founders of the Tree Nursery. 

The Impact of the initiative

We believe that we will have an educational impact and important role in the ecological restoration of forests and damaged landscapes. We have the knowledge, tools and experience to propagate and conserve trees, plants and seeds. A bigger nursery will give us the opportunity to produce more plants and better support our partner projects, collaborators and visitors, who often request various plants from us.

The installation of a nursery for native and rare tree species, some of which are endangered in our country, is an important educational and ecological contribution towards the recovery of traditional varieties.

The nursery will be open to the public and will also be used as a facility to educate visitors (schools and public) about the importance of these species for sustainability, balance and resilience of biodiversity and ecosystems.

This initiative also will be used in the training of adults, and forest awareness for schools. We are able to receive school groups as well as being able to go to teach in other institutions.

The agroforestry is a large biosphere carbon sink: forest can store in long-term full amounts of carbon, either in plant material or soil organic matter. Your collaboration with this initiave will be a direct and indirect support for this positive effect. 

One of our aims is also to allow initiatives like Janas Ecovillage Tree Nursey to be replicated in other places. We are capable of and motivated to give support for starting nursery projects with biodiverse plants and seeds and also more advanced technical knowledge, such as in wood building, heating and aquaponics systems. We will work together in partneship with WWOOF Portugal (https://www.wwoof.pt/pt)  and Associação Plantar Uma Árvore (http://www.plantarumaarvore.org/)  among other related initiaves. 

A medium and long term vision is to create local and regional governmental partnerships so we can work together with local authorities and policies. Our tree nursery will be important to support a bank of plants and seeds for biodiversity.


Risks and Challenges

We are very realistic about the risks involved in the new tree nursery project. Although we have the experience and technical skills to run and maintain a nursery, a permanent structure with heater and aquaponics systems comes along with maintenance costs, costs that we can oversee, count on and already incorporate into our budget plan. This fundraising campaign is to support the initial investments. We know that in the medium and long term we need to create a self-sustainable model of operation and support. 

It is always a challenge for a starting initiative to establish, grow and create a group of local and regional partners, collaborators and customers. One of our greatest challenges is to get people involved and to establish local/regional governmental partnerships and support. For this we aim to create a communication plan with original design and advertising with regular news and developments of the nursery construction.


Other Ways You Can Help

There are other ways to you to support us:

- Come visit us, share and inspire all around you so together we can grow forests! Visit our website at www.ecoaldeiajanas.org  

- Visit our social networks and share our work: www.facebook.com/ecoaldeiajanas

- Donate equipment (wooden nursery, heater and aquaponics system)

- Donate trees, plants and seeds

- Lend us your hands!

We are located in Rua do Luzio, Janas 2710-267 Sintra, Portugal. Our phone number is +351  219291172.

___________________________________________________________________

Breve Descrição

A Ecoaldeia de Janas é um colectivo de pessoas unidas na construção e vivência de um centro de educação não formal para a sustentabilidade prática. Estamos sediados numa das paisagens do conhecido Parque Natural Sintra-Cascais, património mundial da UNESCO e referência da conservação da natureza nacional. Este colectivo trabalha activamente desde 2012 na construção e desenvolvimento deste centro educativo, aplicando e partilhando soluções práticas e inovadoras em prol de uma maior resiliência à escala local e regional. 

Os objectivos desta iniciativa estão baseados no desenvolvimento da experiência e técnica através de uma aprendizagem contínua e prática nos diversos temas e elementos da sustentabilidade que são efectivamente necessários para atingir um sistema ecológico e social em equilíbrio. 

Este colectivo tem vindo a construir uma rede coesa de colaboradores, alunos, formadores e técnicos e residentes através de diversas actividades, serviços e produções locais: agrofloresta, viveiros florestais e agrícolas, apicultura natural, ofícios manuais e tradicionais, carpintaria e construção natural, restauro ecológico, consultadoria ambiental e design, educação e formação, produção local e artesanal (conserva saloia de frutas e vegetais, cerveja  e sidra artesanal, cogumelos, entre outras).

O foco em trabalhar a recuperação da paisagem ecológica (solo, biodiversidade vegetal e animal) foi desde o início uma das principais áreas de intevenção prioritárias na Ecoaldeia de Janas.

Após quatro anos neste trabalho activo de restauro ecológico a paisagem onde estamos sediados é um exemplo vivo e um caso de estudo de uma sucessão ecológica eficaz com elevados índices de aumento de biodiversidade e produtividade (biomassa, vegetação, forragem, qualidade do solo, animais auxiliares e de pastoreio, abelhas, retenção e disponibilidade de água, entre outras). 

Ao longo deste tempo e conjuntamente com o centro de formação e visão pedagógica, temos vindo a adquirir diversas capacidades técnicas na propagação de plantas (sementes, herbáceas, arbustos e árvores) e partilhado este conhecimento prático com colaboradores, formadores e alunos das actividades formativas.

Nos anos pioneiros construímos um pequeno viveiro agroflorestal e local para suportar a visão e o plano de recuperação ecológica da paisagem. Este viveiro também permitiu o apoio a outras iniciativas e parcerias locais e regionais com objectivos semelhantes e com necessidades em adquirir plantas e árvores com qualidade e biodiversidade para diversas funções ecológicas. Neste momento temos mais de quatro mil variedades de plantas de árvores e arbustos no viveiro e prevê-se já neste ano corrente atingir os dez mil exemplares. 

Este é o momento certo para dar o grande salto, partilhar a nossa experiência, conhecimento e capacidades técnicas e ter um maior impacto no desenvolvimento da restauração ecológica através da implementação de um viveiro de árvores com maior dimensão e capacidade.

O nosso principal objectivo é a implementação de um viveiro de grande escala para produção diversa de espécies de árvores, arbustos e plantas herbáceas, classificadas em três áreas principais de acção e investigação:

     

(i) investigação, recuperação, propagação e conservação de variedades de plantas nativas e tradicionais (naturalmente adaptadas ao clima e condições abióticas de Portugal);

(ii) investigação, propagação, conservação e introdução de variedades de árvores adaptadas ao clima mediterrânico e com elevado potencial e diversas funções ecológicas para sistemas agroflorestais e recuperação de ecossistemas;

(iii) investigação, recuperação, propagação e conservação de árvores frutíferas e variedades tradicionais para alimentação humana (naturalmente adaptadas ao clima e condições abióticas de Portugal);


O que precisamos e o que recebes

Para implementar o projecto de construção do viveiro florestal de uma forma estável e sustentável estamos a necessitar, nesta fase inicial, de um suporte colaborativo de 4.900 euros (5.600 dólares). Este é o montante mínimo considerado nesta campanha e que tem como objectivo angariar o mínimo essencial para o arranque do projecto e etapas iniciais de investimento, numa iniciativa que pretende produzir mais de 20 000 árvores no segundo ano de implementação. 


 

O montante angariado e previsto nesta campanha colaborativa será repartido em três áreas principais de construção e implementação:

(i) um viveiro de 80 m2 de estrutura em madeira e vidro e com bancadas próprias de propagação de plantas. A equipa da Ecoaldeia de Janas suporta os processos construtivos da estrutura.

(ii) um queimador de biomassa que vai funcionar como aquecedor para a regulação da temperatura de inverno, fundamental para manter as condições bióticas e abióticas para a conservação e manutenção das plantas em estufa (principalmente para as espécies raras e em perigo de extinção, reduzindo assim a probabilidade de perdas)

(iii) a instalação de um sistema de aquaponia que vai garantir um sistema combinado e em circuito fechado para fertilizar as plantas, garantir as necessidades nutricionais, aumentar a produtividade e reduzir os resíduos através da reutilização dos subprodutos. 

Todo o orçamento está dimensionado para garantir a quantidade mínima de investimento que é necessária para implementar a fase de arranque do viveiro de árvores agroflorestais. Se não atingirmos esta meta colaborativa, iniciaremos apenas com a instalação da estufa de madeira e bancadas de propagação de plantas e sementes de árvores.

Ao colaborares com esta campanha, o que podes ganhar está estritamente relacionado com o impacto da iniciativa (ver a próxima secção) que entre outras possibilidades, ressalvamos as seguintes: visitar, aprender e praticar  com técnicos experientes, como implementar e manter um viveiro combinado com três sistemas (propagação, queimador de biomassa e aquaponia), ter acesso e adquirir a biodiversidade de plantas e sementes para diversas funções, ter suporte técnico para serviços exteriores de design ecológico e restauro agroflorestal e colaborar com um projecto que actua directamente como sumidouro de carbono devido ao papel importante que a árvore tem neste sentido.

A campanha de angariação de fundos está dividida por diversos retornos e vantagens em biodiversidade e quantidades de plantas ou sementes para instalares a tua agrofloresta (etapas iniciais ou avançadas). Ao colaborares vais poder receber sementes, tubérculos, plantas, árvores de fruto e indicadas para a agrofloresta. Poderás também participar em acções de formação sobre agrofloresta na Ecoaldeia de Janas e obter um certificado como co-fundador deste viveiro de árvores. 


Impacto da Iniciativa

Acreditamos que teremos um impacto significativo e um papel educacional importante na restauração ecológica de florestas, agroflorestas e paisagens danificadas pela intervenção humana ao longo das ultimas décadas. Estamos capacitados com conhecimento, ferramentas, técnicas e experiência na propagação e conservação de plantas florestais, arbustivas e herbáceas e sementes. Um viveiro florestal com maior dimensão vai trazer a possibilidade de produzir (propagar) uma maior quantidade de plantas e suportar melhor os projectos parceiros com actividades semelhantes ou colaboradores e visitantes que necessitam de adquirir plantas com grande variedade de funções e riqueza em espécies diversas. 

A criação de um viveiro com três grandes áreas de intervenção de regeneração florestal (plantas nativas, plantas mediterrânicas e raras com elevado potencial, plantas frutíferas tradicionais) tem uma contribuição pedagógica e ecológica muito importante na recuperação de espécies, muitas delas com risco de extinção ou em perigo. 

Este novo viveiro estará aberto ao público e será utilizado para facilitar acções de formação aos visitantes (público em geral, grupos escolares, etc) com grande foco na sensibilização sobre a importância da preservação das espécies para o equilíbrio e resiliência da biodiversidade nos ecossistemas agroflorestais. 

Esta iniciativa vai permitir ter um espaço aberto e preparado para receber e facilitar acções de formação para adultos e acções de sensibilização para grupos e escolas. Estaremos igualmente disponíveis para levar o nosso trabalho e conhecimento às escolas e instituições da região.

A agrofloresta é um grande sumidouro de carbono da biosfera: as florestas podem acumular a longo prazo grandes quantidades de carbono, quer no material vegetal, quer na matéria orgânica. São diversos os relatórios científicos e acordos intergovernamentais para o combate às alterações climáticas que referem a importância da conservação e reflorestação das florestas por estas serem consideradas um dos reservatórios de carbono mais importantes à escala global e local. O aumento da área destes ecossistemas terá um impacte positivo na capacidade de sumidouro de carbono da biosfera e ao colaborares com esta iniciativa estás a suportar directa e indirectamente este efeito positivo. Vamos propagar plantas, árvores e sementes para a instalação de agroflorestas e sumidouros de carbono e o teu apoio é essencial. 

Um dos nossos objectivos vai passar também por dar a oportunidade de iniciativas como o viveiro florestal de Janas poder ser replicado noutras localidades do país. Estamos capacitados e motivados para colaborar com quem quiser iniciar um viveiro com grande variedade em espécies de plantas e sementes, incluindo o suporte técnico de um sistema combinado (estrutura em madeira e vidro, bancadas de propagação, aquecimento a biomassa e aquaponia). Entre alguns parceiros destacamos a colaboração com a plataforma de voluntariado WWOOF Portugal (https://www.wwoof.pt/pt) e a Associação Plantar Uma Árvore  (http://www.plantarumaarvore.org/) . 

A visão a médio e longo prazo passa muito pela criação de parcerias estratégicas com as instituições governamentais da região para que possamos trabalhar em conjunto com as políticas de intervenção local e regional. Neste sentido, o viveiro florestal de Janas terá um papel importante na criação de um banco de sementes e plantas da região, nativas, tradicionais, raras e com grande potencial ecológico de regeneração. 


Riscos e desafios

Estamos conscientes dos riscos envolvidos na construção de um novo e maior viveiro de árvores e plantas. Estamos capacitados com experiência, técnicas e ferramentas para desenvolver e manter um viveiro e propagação de plantas em bancadas e a instalação de um sistema de combinado de aquecimento e de aquaponia, o que implica custos adicionais de manutenção e que estão considerados nesta etapa inicial. Esta campanha de angariação tem o objectivo de suportar o arranque e investimentos iniciais da instalação de um viveiro. Está planeado a criação de um modelo sustentável para o funcionamento de todo o projecto, a médio e longo prazo.

É sempre um desafio encontrar um equilíbrio estável de uma iniciativa que está em crescimento, incluindo a ligação com as parcerias locais e regionais, colaboradores e visitantes. Um dos nossos grandes desafios será levar as pessoas a envolverem-se no projecto e a suportarem a nossa visão e estabelecer parcerias estratégicas com as instituições governamentais locais e regionais. Para este fim, desenhamos um plano de comunicação com um design original que garanta a publicação regular de notícias com os desenvolvimentos da implementação e funcionamento de todo o projecto a curto, médio e longo prazo. 


Outras formas de colaborares

Existem outras formas de colaborares com esta iniciativa:
- Visita-nos, partilha e passa a mensagem. Juntos podemos plantar e restaurar florestas. Visita o nosso website em www.ecoaldeiajanas.org
- Vista as nossas redes sociais e partilha a campanha de angariação de fundos em www.facebook.com/ecoaldeiajanas
- Faz donativos em géneros de equipamento para as três áreas principais de implementação do viveiro (viveiro em madeira e vidro, aquecimento a biomassa e sistema de aquaponia)
- Faz donativos em árvores, plantas e sementes
- Colabora com voluntariado e vem ajudar!
Estamos localizados na  Rua do Luzio, Janas 2710-267  Sintra, Portugal. O nosso número é +351 219291172
story_txt:
Short SummaryJanas Ecovillage is a collective of people working together in order to build and bring to life a non-formal educational
centre for sustainability. We are located in Janas, in the beautiful landscapes of the UNESCO Sintra World Heritage site. We have been working actively since 2012 in building this centre, applying and sharing practical and
innovative solutions towards greater resilience at the local and regional level. 
The aims of this initiative are based on practical skills and experiences and learning by doing in the various areas of sustainability that are necessary to reach a more balanced eco-social system. We have building a network of collaborators, students, trainers and residents through diverse activities,
local services and products: agroforestry, nurseries and seed banks, regenerative agriculture, natural beekeeping, handicrafts, carpentry and natural building, ecological restoration, environmental consultancy and design,
education and course teachings, local products (canned fruit and veg, homemade beer, cider and mushrooms).
The focus and work in landscape recovery (soil, plant and animal biodiversity) was from the beginning one of the
main areas of intervention in Janas Ecovillage. 
After four years of this active restoration work our landscape is a living example and case study of an effective ecological succession with an
increase in biodiversity and productivity (biomass, vegetation, food, forage, soil quality, animals, bees, water retention and availability, etc).
Throughout this time of working towards the vision for an educational and training centre, we have become skilled
in diverse techniques of plant propagation (seeds, herbaceous plants, shrubs and trees) and shared this knowledge with collaborators, teachers and students. We have built a small local agroforestry nursery to sustain our vision
and active work in ecological restoration. With that we were also able to support other local and regional initiatives with similar objectives and the need for a biodiverse range of quality plants and trees to serve various
ecological functions. At the moment we have more than four thousand tree and shrub plants in our original nursery and predict to reach twenty thousand these current year. 
Now is the right moment to make a big leap, to share our experience, knowledge and skills and have a bigger impactin ecological restoration at the local, regional and also national
level, with the building and establishment of a larger forest-tree nursery.
Our main objective is to create a large nursery to produce trees, shrubs and perennial plant species, in three main
areas of action and research: 






(i) research, recovery, propagation and conservation of native and traditional plant and tree varieties (naturally adapted to the climatic and biotic conditions of Portugal)
(ii) research, propagation, conservation and introduction of trees and plants adapted to Mediterranean climates with high potential and diverse ecological functions for agroforestry and ecosystem restoration.
(iii) research, recovery, propagation and conservation of traditional fruit tree varieties for human food products (naturally adapted to the climatic and biotic conditions of Portugal)What We Need and What You Can GetTo set our project on stable feet from the beginning we will need a total amount of 4,900 euros (5,600 US dollars). This
fundraising campaign aims to obtain the minimum amount considered essential for the start-up and first investment, in a initiative that intends to produce more than 20,000 trees in the second year.





Of this ideal fundraising budget, the amount will be divided and flow into three main areas of construction and
implementation:
(i) an 80 square metre nursery of wood and glass with plant propagation
benches. TheJanas Ecovillage team will support all the technical construction works. 
(ii) a biomass burner as a heater for winter temperature regulation, which
is very important to maintain the biotic and abiotic conditions for the preservation and maintenance of nursery plants (mainly for the endangered species and the new rare varieties, reducing the probability of losses).
(iii) an aquaponics system that will assure a combined and closed system
for providing fertility to the plants, assuring nutrient supply, increasing productivity and reducing waste through reuse of by-products.
All the budget is calculated to support the minimum amount that we need to create this tree nursery. If we don't
reach our entire goal we will get started with the wooden nursery and benches to propagate our trees, plants and seeds.
What you can get is closely related to the impact of the initiative (see next section) which among other possibilities,
includes the following: you will be able to visit, learn and practise how to install and maintain a nursery structure combined with three systems (propagation benches, biomass burner and aquaponics), to have access to a biodiverse
range of plants and seeds with various functions, to receive our technical support with ecological restoration and agroforestry design, and to support a project that acts directly as a carbon sink through the important role that trees play.



The funding campaing perks is divided by the amount of plant or seed diversity you can get to implement your agroforestry project (first or advanced steps). You can get seeds, tubers, plants, fruit trees and agroforestry indicated trees. You will be able to participate in agroforestry trainnings in Janas Ecovillage and also certificates as you will be one of the founders of the Tree Nursery. 
The Impact of the initiative

We believe that we will have an educational impact and important role in the ecological restoration of forests and
damaged landscapes. We have the knowledge, tools and experience to propagate and conserve trees, plants and seeds. A bigger nursery will give us the opportunity to produce more plants and better support our partner projects,
collaborators and visitors, who often request various plants from us.
The installation of a nursery for native and rare tree species, some of which are endangered in our country, is
an important educational and ecological contribution towards the recovery of traditional varieties.
The nursery will be open to the public and will also be used as a facility to educate visitors (schools and public) about the importance of these
species for sustainability, balance and resilience of biodiversity and ecosystems.
This initiative also will be used in the training of adults, and forest awareness for schools. We are able to
receive school groups as well as being able to go to teach in other institutions.
The agroforestry is a large biosphere carbon sink: forest can store in long-term full amounts of carbon, either in plant material or soil organic matter. Your collaboration with this initiave will be a direct and indirect support for this positive effect. 
One of our aims is also to allow initiatives like Janas Ecovillage Tree Nursey to be replicated in other places.
We are capable of and motivated to give support for starting nursery projects with biodiverse plants and seeds and also more advanced technical knowledge, such as in wood building, heating and aquaponics systems. We will work together in partneship with WWOOF Portugal (https://www.wwoof.pt/pt)  and Associação Plantar Uma Árvore (http://www.plantarumaarvore.org/)  among other related initiaves. 
A medium and long term vision is to create local and regional governmental partnerships so we can work together
with local authorities and policies. Our tree nursery will be important to support a bank of plants and seeds for biodiversity.




Risks and ChallengesWe are very realistic about the risks involved in the new tree nursery project. Although we have the experience
and technical skills to run and maintain a nursery, a permanent structure with heater and aquaponics systems comes along with maintenance costs, costs that we can oversee, count on and already incorporate into our budget plan.
This fundraising campaign is to support the initial investments. We know that in the medium and long term we need to create a self-sustainable model of operation and support. 
It is always a challenge for a starting initiative to establish, grow and create a group of local and regional partners,
collaborators and customers. One of our greatest challenges is to get people involved and to establish local/regional governmental partnerships and support. For this we aim to create a communication plan with original design
and advertising with regular news and developments of the nursery construction.
Other Ways You Can Help
There are other ways to you to support us:
- Come visit us, share and inspire all around you so together we can grow forests! Visit our website at www.ecoaldeiajanas.org  - Visit our social networks and share our work: www.facebook.com/ecoaldeiajanas- Donate equipment (wooden nursery, heater and aquaponics system)
- Donate trees, plants and seeds
- Lend us your hands!
We are located in Rua do Luzio, Janas 2710-267 Sintra, Portugal. Our phone number is +351  219291172.___________________________________________________________________Breve Descrição
A Ecoaldeia de Janas é um colectivo de pessoas unidas na construção e vivência de um centro de educação não formal para a sustentabilidade prática. Estamos sediados numa das paisagens do conhecido Parque Natural Sintra-Cascais, património mundial da UNESCO e referência da conservação da natureza nacional. Este colectivo trabalha activamente desde 2012 na construção e desenvolvimento deste centro educativo, aplicando e partilhando soluções práticas e inovadoras em prol de uma maior resiliência à escala local e regional. 
Os objectivos desta iniciativa estão baseados no desenvolvimento da experiência e técnica através de uma aprendizagem contínua e prática nos diversos temas e elementos da sustentabilidade que são efectivamente necessários para atingir um sistema ecológico e social em equilíbrio. 
Este colectivo tem vindo a construir uma rede coesa de colaboradores, alunos, formadores e técnicos e residentes através de diversas actividades, serviços e produções locais: agrofloresta, viveiros florestais e agrícolas, apicultura natural, ofícios manuais e tradicionais, carpintaria e construção natural, restauro ecológico, consultadoria ambiental e design, educação e formação, produção local e artesanal (conserva saloia de frutas e vegetais, cerveja  e sidra artesanal, cogumelos, entre outras).
O foco em trabalhar a recuperação da paisagem ecológica (solo, biodiversidade vegetal e animal) foi desde o início uma das principais áreas de intevenção prioritárias na Ecoaldeia de Janas.
Após quatro anos neste trabalho activo de restauro ecológico a paisagem onde estamos sediados é um exemplo vivo e um caso de estudo de uma sucessão ecológica eficaz com elevados índices de aumento de biodiversidade e produtividade (biomassa, vegetação, forragem, qualidade do solo, animais auxiliares e de pastoreio, abelhas, retenção e disponibilidade de água, entre outras). 
Ao longo deste tempo e conjuntamente com o centro de formação e visão pedagógica, temos vindo a adquirir diversas capacidades técnicas na propagação de plantas (sementes, herbáceas, arbustos e árvores) e partilhado este conhecimento prático com colaboradores, formadores e alunos das actividades formativas.
Nos anos pioneiros construímos um pequeno viveiro agroflorestal e local para suportar a visão e o plano de recuperação ecológica da paisagem. Este viveiro também permitiu o apoio a outras iniciativas e parcerias locais e regionais com objectivos semelhantes e com necessidades em adquirir plantas e árvores com qualidade e biodiversidade para diversas funções ecológicas. Neste momento temos mais de quatro mil variedades de plantas de árvores e arbustos no viveiro e prevê-se já neste ano corrente atingir os dez mil exemplares. 
Este é o momento certo para dar o grande salto, partilhar a nossa experiência, conhecimento e capacidades técnicas e ter um maior impacto no desenvolvimento da restauração ecológica através da implementação de um viveiro de árvores com maior dimensão e capacidade.
O nosso principal objectivo é a implementação de um viveiro de grande escala para produção diversa de espécies de árvores, arbustos e plantas herbáceas, classificadas em três áreas principais de acção e investigação:

     


(i) investigação, recuperação, propagação e conservação de variedades de plantas nativas e tradicionais (naturalmente adaptadas ao clima e condições abióticas de Portugal);
(ii) investigação, propagação, conservação e introdução de variedades de árvores adaptadas ao clima mediterrânico e com elevado potencial e diversas funções ecológicas para sistemas agroflorestais e recuperação de ecossistemas;
(iii) investigação, recuperação, propagação e conservação de árvores frutíferas e variedades tradicionais para alimentação humana (naturalmente adaptadas ao clima e condições abióticas de Portugal);


O que precisamos e o que recebes

Para implementar o projecto de construção do viveiro florestal de uma forma estável e sustentável estamos a necessitar, nesta fase inicial, de um suporte colaborativo de 4.900 euros (5.600 dólares). Este é o montante mínimo considerado nesta campanha e que tem como objectivo angariar o mínimo essencial para o arranque do projecto e etapas iniciais de investimento, numa iniciativa que pretende produzir mais de 20 000 árvores no segundo ano de implementação. 


 
O montante angariado e previsto nesta campanha colaborativa será repartido em três áreas principais de construção e implementação:
(i) um viveiro de 80 m2 de estrutura em madeira e vidro e com bancadas próprias de propagação de plantas. A equipa da Ecoaldeia de Janas suporta os processos construtivos da estrutura.
(ii) um queimador de biomassa que vai funcionar como aquecedor para a regulação da temperatura de inverno, fundamental para manter as condições bióticas e abióticas para a conservação e manutenção das plantas em estufa (principalmente para as espécies raras e em perigo de extinção, reduzindo assim a probabilidade de perdas)
(iii) a instalação de um sistema de aquaponia que vai garantir um sistema combinado e em circuito fechado para fertilizar as plantas, garantir as necessidades nutricionais, aumentar a produtividade e reduzir os resíduos através da reutilização dos subprodutos. 
Todo o orçamento está dimensionado para garantir a quantidade mínima de investimento que é necessária para implementar a fase de arranque do viveiro de árvores agroflorestais. Se não atingirmos esta meta colaborativa, iniciaremos apenas com a instalação da estufa de madeira e bancadas de propagação de plantas e sementes de árvores.
Ao colaborares com esta campanha, o que podes ganhar está estritamente relacionado com o impacto da iniciativa (ver a próxima secção) que entre outras possibilidades, ressalvamos as seguintes: visitar, aprender e praticar  com técnicos experientes, como implementar e manter um viveiro combinado com três sistemas (propagação, queimador de biomassa e aquaponia), ter acesso e adquirir a biodiversidade de plantas e sementes para diversas funções, ter suporte técnico para serviços exteriores de design ecológico e restauro agroflorestal e colaborar com um projecto que actua directamente como sumidouro de carbono devido ao papel importante que a árvore tem neste sentido.
A campanha de angariação de fundos está dividida por diversos retornos e vantagens em biodiversidade e quantidades de plantas ou sementes para instalares a tua agrofloresta (etapas iniciais ou avançadas). Ao colaborares vais poder receber sementes, tubérculos, plantas, árvores de fruto e indicadas para a agrofloresta. Poderás também participar em acções de formação sobre agrofloresta na Ecoaldeia de Janas e obter um certificado como co-fundador deste viveiro de árvores. 



Impacto da Iniciativa

Acreditamos que teremos um impacto significativo e um papel educacional importante na restauração ecológica de
florestas, agroflorestas e paisagens danificadas pela intervenção humana ao longo das ultimas décadas. Estamos capacitados com conhecimento, ferramentas, técnicas e experiência na propagação e conservação de plantas
florestais, arbustivas e herbáceas e sementes. Um viveiro florestal com maior dimensão vai trazer a possibilidade de produzir (propagar) uma maior quantidade de plantas e suportar melhor os projectos parceiros com actividades
semelhantes ou colaboradores e visitantes que necessitam de adquirir plantas com grande variedade de funções e riqueza em espécies diversas. 
A criação de um viveiro com três grandes áreas de intervenção de regeneração florestal (plantas nativas,
plantas mediterrânicas e raras com elevado potencial, plantas frutíferas tradicionais) tem uma contribuição pedagógica e ecológica muito importante na recuperação de espécies, muitas delas com risco de extinção
ou em perigo. 
Este novo viveiro estará aberto ao público e será utilizado para facilitar acções de formação aos visitantes
(público em geral, grupos escolares, etc) com grande foco na sensibilização sobre a importância da preservação das espécies para o equilíbrio e resiliência da biodiversidade nos ecossistemas agroflorestais. 
Esta iniciativa vai permitir ter um espaço aberto e preparado para receber e facilitar acções de formação para
adultos e acções de sensibilização para grupos e escolas. Estaremos igualmente disponíveis para levar o nosso trabalho e conhecimento às escolas e instituições da região.
A agrofloresta é um grande sumidouro de carbono da biosfera: as florestas podem acumular a longo prazo grandes quantidades de carbono, quer no material vegetal, quer na matéria orgânica. São diversos os relatórios científicos e acordos intergovernamentais para o combate às alterações climáticas que referem a importância da conservação e reflorestação das florestas por estas serem consideradas um dos reservatórios de carbono mais importantes à escala global e local. O aumento da área destes ecossistemas terá um impacte positivo na capacidade de sumidouro de carbono da biosfera e ao colaborares com esta iniciativa estás a suportar directa e indirectamente este efeito positivo. Vamos propagar plantas, árvores e sementes para a instalação de agroflorestas e sumidouros de carbono e o teu apoio é essencial. 
Um dos nossos objectivos vai passar também por dar a oportunidade de iniciativas como o viveiro florestal de Janas
poder ser replicado noutras localidades do país. Estamos capacitados e motivados para colaborar com quem quiser iniciar um viveiro com grande variedade em espécies de plantas e sementes, incluindo o suporte técnico de um
sistema combinado (estrutura em madeira e vidro, bancadas de propagação, aquecimento a biomassa e aquaponia). Entre alguns parceiros destacamos a colaboração com a plataforma de voluntariado WWOOF Portugal (https://www.wwoof.pt/pt) e a Associação Plantar Uma Árvore  (http://www.plantarumaarvore.org/) . 
A visão a médio e longo prazo passa muito pela criação de parcerias estratégicas com as instituições governamentais
da região para que possamos trabalhar em conjunto com as políticas de intervenção local e regional. Neste sentido, o viveiro florestal de Janas terá um papel importante na criação de um banco de sementes e plantas da
região, nativas, tradicionais, raras e com grande potencial ecológico de regeneração. 



Riscos e desafios
Estamos conscientes dos riscos envolvidos na construção de um novo e maior viveiro de árvores e plantas. Estamos capacitados com experiência, técnicas e ferramentas para desenvolver e manter um viveiro e propagação de plantas em bancadas e a instalação de um sistema de combinado de aquecimento e de aquaponia, o que implica custos adicionais de manutenção e que estão considerados nesta etapa inicial. Esta campanha de angariação tem o objectivo de suportar o arranque e investimentos iniciais da instalação de um viveiro. Está planeado a criação de um modelo sustentável para o funcionamento de todo o projecto, a médio e longo prazo.
É sempre um desafio encontrar um equilíbrio estável de uma iniciativa que está em crescimento, incluindo a ligação com as parcerias locais e regionais, colaboradores e visitantes. Um dos nossos grandes desafios será levar as pessoas a envolverem-se no projecto e a suportarem a nossa visão e estabelecer parcerias estratégicas com as instituições governamentais locais e regionais. Para este fim, desenhamos um plano de comunicação com um design original que garanta a publicação regular de notícias com os desenvolvimentos da implementação e funcionamento de todo o projecto a curto, médio e longo prazo. 

Outras formas de colaborares

Existem outras formas de colaborares com esta iniciativa:
- Visita-nos, partilha e passa a mensagem. Juntos podemos plantar e restaurar florestas. Visita o nosso website em www.ecoaldeiajanas.org

- Vista as nossas redes sociais e partilha a campanha de angariação de fundos em www.facebook.com/ecoaldeiajanas

- Faz donativos em géneros de equipamento para as três áreas principais de implementação do viveiro (viveiro em madeira e vidro, aquecimento a biomassa e sistema de aquaponia)
- Faz donativos em árvores, plantas e sementes
- Colabora com voluntariado e vem ajudar!
Estamos localizados na  Rua do Luzio, Janas 2710-267  Sintra, Portugal. O nosso número é +351 219291172

story:
The Flipside Rides TV show is going to entertain and educate the public about alternative fuel vehicles.  Your contributions will help produce a pilot show which will be presented to networks, stations and potential sponsors.  FSR is NOT a web video but rather will be a nationally broadcast weekly show and later syndicated worldwide.

Wait a minute!  Gas prices are always fluctuating so why should you care? Because alternative fuels are the future.

If every major car company from General Motors to Mercedes were not designing and testing AFV's then you might have second thoughts.  But all you have to do is look around to see their initial designs already on the road.  Watch the news and you'll hear about hundreds more on the drawing board or in development.

So how is the public going to learn more about these AFV's?  By watching a fun weekly TV show dedicated to new vehicles being introduced, and we'll take a look at the creative individuals and backyard geniuses who are converting their old fossil burners.


View the Gallery to see some of the vehicles and concepts we'll be checking in on at Flipside Rides.


Reaching our dollar goal will allow us to produce a top-quality pilot which we will then present to stations and networks.  The first time I followed this plan our show went national immediately.  I sincerely believe Flipside Rides will be a bigger success than my first show (and that show/series lasted for almost 10 years on PBS).  The subject is timely, exciting and good for the planet.  Let's work together and make this happen.

Have a look at the cars, the people and companies behind the technology, and peer into the future of Alternative Fuel Vehicles!


I'm Dale Morris - IMDB Info

My expertise is producing a quality, weekly show that the average person will enjoy.  I have many years of experience putting together the right team members from camera operators to top notch editors.  I know where to locate undiscovered talent at reasonable rates which of course helps the company's bottom line and the show/series longevity.

I like being ahead of the pack.  My last TV series was the first weekly classic car show to be broadcast on a national scale.  It was aired on PBS for 9+ years.   270 shows were produced averaging 150 stations each week and syndicated in 11 countries with some of the largest companies in the U.S. sponsoring us.

Unfortunately, cancer struck and I was forced to give up on every thing I had worked so hard for.  After many years of battles I can finally classify myself a lucky survivor and begin again.

I believe Flipside Rides is timely, trending and will be even more popular!


Thanks for the opportunity to bring you an entertaining and informative show. AFV's are here to stay and will only become more popular and more technically sound. Get on the wagon with us and go on a Flipside Ride!

drawing board or in development.  
So how is the public going to learn more about these AFV's?                                                  
  By watching a fun weekly TV show dedicated to new vehicles being introduced, and we'll take a look at the  creative individuals and backyard geniuses who are converting their old
 fossil burners.


View the Gallery to see some of the vehicles and concepts we'll be checking in on at Flipside Rides.


Reaching our dollar goal will allow us to produce a top-quality pilot which we will then present to stations and networks.  The first time I followed this plan our show went national immediately.  I sincerely believe Flipside Rides will be a bigger success than my first show (and that show/series lasted for almost 10 years on PBS).  The subject is timely, exciting and good for the planet.  Let's work together and make this happen.
Have a look at the cars, the people and companies behind the technology, and peer into the future of Alternative Fuel Vehicles!





 
I'm Dale Morris - IMDB Info

My expertise is producing a quality, weekly show that the average 
person will enjoy.    I have many years of experience putting together 
the right team members from camera operators to top notch editors.    I 
know where to locate undiscovered talent at reasonable rates  which of 
course helps the company's bottom line and the show/series longevity.
I like being ahead of the pack.    My last TV series was the first weekly classic car show to be broadcast  on a national scale.  It was aired on PBS for 9+ years.   270 shows 
were produced averaging 150 stations each week and syndicated in 11 
countries with some of the largest companies in the U.S. sponsoring us.
Unfortunately, cancer struck and I was forced to give up on every thing I had worked so hard for.  After many years of battles I can finally classify myself a lucky survivor and begin again.
I believe Flipside Rides is timely, trending and will be even more popular!

 Thanks for the opportunity to bring you an entertaining and informative show. AFV's are here to stay and will only become more popular and more technically sound. Get on the wagon with us and go on a Flipside Ride!

story:
Baby Sea Serpents Eat Pollution!

SLURPITS™ are like probiotics for the planet! Inspired by the symbiotic relationship that exists in coral and our gut, SLURPITS are the first living biofilters that absorb and digest both oil and pesticides in the water.  We use a patented system that combines natural and man made materials with over fifty species of natural, Non-GMO beneficial bacteria. These are EPA registered and certified pathogen free, and safe. SLURPITS are designed for docks, storm drains and ditches, anywhere there is pollution in the water. They create a reservoir of super good bugs that colonize their surroundings, with each species taking a bite out of the toxins, leaving food available for the next bug, until there is just carbon dioxide and water leftover! 

Since 1994 my company, Waterflowers Ecological Design, has been tackling pollution. While working on golf courses I learned that some pesticide manufacturers cleaned the residue in their tanks with bacteria! I was so amazed that something could consume poison for food that I learned more about bacterial bio-augmentation and set up some living filters where mowers and sprayers were cleaned. This worked so well that it inspired me to create the living sculpture, “Earth Serpent”  for the city of Cambridge to protect its water supply, the Fresh Pond Reservoir, with this technology. This sucess led to the subsequent creation of two, 100 foot sea serpents named “Slurpy” and “Sylvie” in Salem/Beverly Mass.

 Now we have perfected and patented the technology to create  their progeny, the SLURPITS. 

Through this crowd fund we are seeking partners. People like yourself, who care about the environment and want to clean it up. We have already partnered with the Palm Beach Habilitation Center to make the SLURPITS, providing jobs for disabled Americans. We have also partnered with ShipMonk to fulfill our orders. We invite you to partner with us to clean the water. Twenty five dollars will get you a sweet “Save the Humans” T shirt with our Sea Serpent logo. For $50 your reward will be your own SLURPIT. Even better, $100 and you receive one and we will send one to your mayor with instructions on how to clean the water. For $500 we ship you 12 SLURPITS and for$1,000 dollars we have original art. This is a limited series about adapting to climate change. Of course if all you really want for any amount is our sweet “Save the Humans” T shirt we can work it out.

Become a partner and help us set up our demonstration sites and scale up this clean tech enterprise! Your support will go into creating more SLURPITS and creating more jobs dedicated to cleaning toxins out of our environment. Our $30,000 budget covers the cost of fulfilling this crowd fund,Here is the breakdown on the cost: Assuming that everyone wants one SLURPIT shipped within the USA for a total of 600 our cost for the product is $9000 shipping $7200 Video/Logo and consultants $ 1500 and 8% fee From Indiegogo and credit cards $2,400. This gives us $9,900 of working capital for business development and the cost of the next 500 SLURPITS. Hopefully some people will give a lot of cash and only want a Tshirt!  The important thing is, there are 600 SLURPITS made by our partners at Palm Beach Habilitation Center eating pollution in our watersheds and all of you will tell your friends! 
Join the SLURPIT team, we look forward to cleaning the toxins from our environment with you.

story:
The Problem

Plastic baling twine is killing wildlife[i], polluting their habitat and producing tons of waste in local landfills. Although it is a useful material for tying bales of hay, the continuous disposal harms the environment. 39,050,000 ft.[ii] of plastic twine is used and discarded every year in the San Luis Valley of south central Colorado. The nearest recycling center is 10 hours driving distance, which is why farmers and ranchers typically burn or bury it.

Why Would You Care?

Apart from the negative impact on wildlife, discarding twine can be detrimental to the human environment. Burned twine releases chemicals that are known to cause cancer and respiratory disease. Buried twine produces toxic chemicals that leach into the soil and groundwater, mainly used for drinking and agriculture. It is important for Colorado, and other states to be aware of this plastic twine problem.

How We Plan to Fix It

Our team has developed a multi-faceted approach to this environmental problem. We have created a statewide team that will develop an educational program and a recycling system. Recycling and re-utilization of the plastic twine is our short term plan. The long term plan is to replace the usage of plastic twine with a biodegradable alternative.This fundraiser, is specifically geared towards gathering funds for buying bins and equipment for collecting, and leveraging other sources of funding. After a collection system is established, the twine will be sent to designated places for recycling and re-purposing.

This project will create new job opportunities, introduce innovative ways of creating a zero waste environment, and will bring the SLV farming community together. It has huge potential for the San Luis Valley, and for rural Colorado.

Please help us reach our goal! [iii]

The Long Term Effects

Eventually our goal is to establish a statewide collection network, in which people can drop off used twine at convenient locations anywhere in Colorado. The collected twine will then be shipped to designated recyclers, or businesses who will repurpose the material. Our vision for the future is that biodegradable materials will replace plastic baling twine on farms across Colorado. We also plan to promote ways of utilizing the material for building, and supplying businesses who will utilize plastic twine as a primary input for product creation and manufacturing.

What We Have Done So Far

Our team has established three collection sites in Southwest Colorado.Our efforts include finding partnering recyclers to make the operation fully functional, and raising awareness about the project itself.  We are currently working with a local business owner who is repurposing discarded plastic twine into adobe building bricks. The team has also worked with micro-enterprises to create various items from the plastic twine (we are offering those as perks when you contribute). We will continue on our quest to find more businesses who will reutilize the material, and create a network of hard-to-recycle material utilization in Colorado, locally and commercially.


[i] Photo of Osprey used in video: Idaho Department of Fish and Game

[ii] Calculated with county specific data from Colorado Agricultural Statistics 2013, with assistance from SLV Colorado State University Extension Service assistance.

[iii] Video Production and Editing Deon Kittrell; Voice Over by T. Alex Riehl; Plastic Twine & Slide artwork by Mary Hoffman; Recycle site coordination by Laura Tyler, Fort Collins Conservation District; Special thanks to Laura Tyler for her partnership, Armando Valdez, Aaron Miltenberger, Erwin Young, Phil Chapnick for their farming/ranching insight and Brock Gallegos for coordination. 




The Different Perks:

Dog Collar 

Yoga Mat

Circular Rug

Dream Catcher 

Farm to Market Wall Hanging

story:
TIDE rangers and the Belize Coast Guard are working hard to protect the Port Honduras Marine Reserve in southern Belize. Help them safeguard its incredible wildlife and resources for present and future generations.

West Snake Caye is one of five replenishment zones currently within Port Honduras Marine Reserve .

Port Honduras Marine Reserve contains some of the most pristine habitat in the entire Mesoamerican Reef Complex. Its coral reefs, mangrove islands and expansive seagrass beds support a healthy population of endangered West Indian manatees, and 18 other globally threatened species, including hawksbill turtles, hammerhead sharks, and American crocodiles.

Map of protected areas in Southern Belize.

With so much healthy seagrass and mangroves, Port Honduras is in an ideal nursery ground for lobster, conch and many species of fish important for local livelihoods. The marine reserve supports approximately 300 fishing families in the most poverty stricken district of Belize. At a time when over half of the world’s fisheries are fully exploited and one quarter have collapsed, it is important that we protect places like this.

Port Honduras Marine Reserve from Google Earth. Bordering terrestrial protected areas to the north, and the town of Punta Gorda to the south.

Illegal fishing is a major problem in southern Belize, especially because of our close proximity to Guatemala and Honduras. Fishers from those countries frequently cross into Belize to illegally exploit Belize’s abundant marine resources.

In an effort to protect the livelihood of fishers, the Belize Fisheries Department and its partners including TIDE introduced a new fisheries management tool called Managed Access (a first for the Caribbean). Under Managed Access, the local fishers identify the historical users of the area, who are granted access to fish commercially. Local fishers have seen the benefits and so the Fisheries Department is now expanding Managed Access to the entire country, a major milestone toward sustainable fishing.

However, all the licensing systems in the world won’t make a difference unless there is a physical enforcement presence on the water. That is why TIDE rangers and the Belize Coast Guard are on the front line, protecting Belize’s natural resources. They conduct patrols day and night, enforcing Managed Access, preventing illegal fishing, removing illegal gill nets and long lines, educating users about the laws and, when necessary, making arrests.

TIDE ranger Edwin accompanied by Belize Coast Guard pulling up an illegal gill net.
TIDE is a non-profit, non-government organization. We rely on donations to continue this important work. So we are reaching out to our friends to help protect Belize’s amazing marine resources for present and future generations.

___________________________
Music in video credit Marine North by @nop (c) 2015 Licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution Noncommercial  (3.0) license. http://ccmixter.org/files/Lancefield/51810

story:
In May 2015, CruzinCobGlobal travelled to Senegal to teach a 2-week Cob Oven & Bench workshop (see photos on Flickr) to African, European and American students to introduce this  important "modernized" earthen building technique in Africa, where traditional earthen construction is in need of Rebirth, Change, New Skills & New Knowledge.  Locals we met were very excited about COB (clay, sand and straw) and the use of traditional building materials in a New Way that would produce Strong, Durable, Unique, and Beautiful buildings.  The "old" traditional earthen buildings are associated with backwardness, poor quality, instability and short lifespans.  Concrete and cement are frowned upon by most people we met, especially the builders, all of whom are gung-ho on being trained in COB construction.  The locals, especially women, were naturally drawn to building low carbon footprint dwellings with low-budget  materials using "modern" techniques.  The time is right and the people are ready.

CruzinCobGlobal's founder Claudine Désirée has been teaching cob workshops and building cob houses since 2004.  In the Spring of 2015 she legalized the FIRST coastal California cob building, with funding from her Indiegogo campaign.  In December 2015 Claudine left her home base of 20 years (Santa Cruz, CA) to begin a 3-year global bike journey introducing West Coast (U.S.) cob techniques to the world at large in the form of multicultural workshops.  She speaks French, Spanish, Portuguese, German and a little Chinese and loves bringing cultures and languages together in her Courses, watching people build gorgeous mud houses and deep friendships in their initiation into cob construction.  She is now building a GlobalCOB team with former students and other experienced cobbers joining CruzinCobGlobal's Life-enhancing mission.

This 28-day December cob workshop will focus on building a young Dutch couple's residence in the small fishing village of Yene Kao, just south of Dakar, Senegal, as a MODEL COB HOUSE for the local and national public to view.   We want half the students to be Senegalese and half from other countries.  We have 10 excited students who will become cob builders and instructors after taking this training.  There are already prospective projects for them to get started on once they are trained.

CruzinCobGlobal has made the course very affordable for all, at 25€/day for the tuition.  We are seeking funding for 10 students which would cover their tuition (500€) and communal lunch (100€) for the month, or 600€ total.  We have photos and short bios for the first 5 students in the Gallery section and we would be happy to give you the contact info of the student you fund either in whole or in part. 

THANKS FOR DOING YOUR PART IN BEAUTIFYING THE PLANET AND FEEDING THE SOUL!

story:
What is Liter of Light Ghana?

Liter of Light Ghana is a growing organization that seeks to provide eco-friendly, cost-effective solar lighting to communities that are deprived or have inadequate access to light. The technology that Liter of Light operates on is one that was developed by 'My Shelter Foundation', an NGO based in the Philippines. Founded by Illiac Diaz, the organization developed this innovative process that marries solar panels with recycled plastic bottles to produce clean, renewable lighting. Along with materials that can be sourced locally, these lights can be installed in electricity-deprived homes.

In a country such as Ghana with well over 300 days of uninterrupted sunlight, it is expedient to harvest this natural source of energy to ameliorate the issue at hand. This technology has been used by the UN and has been adopted in some UNHCR camps worldwide.

The liter of light Ghana team is comprised of young adults with a common goal of improving the lives of people in our beloved country, Ghana, and eventually beyond our country’s borders. The team plans on building and installing solar lanterns for 100 homes this December.

Below are some of the lights the team will be building for the project:

Daylight 

    



Nightlight 



Streetlight




The Problem

Most people would agree that light is a basic necessity of life, to be seen as a right and not a privilege. Unfortunately, many people in the world (approx 1.3 billion) live without access to adequate electricity and thus light. Many small communities in Ghana (especially on the outskirts of town) are not even connected to the national electricity grid. When nighttime comes, most activity (and productivity) slows down considerably and even comes to a halt as there is no adequate lighting to help individuals and families carry out simple tasks. Children rely on candles or health hazardous kerosene lamps to study at night. Apart from straining their eyes to study under the dim, flickering lights these lamps offer, they put their healths at risk by inhaling the toxic kerosene fumes emanating from the lamps.

Many families, who tend to use candles a  lot, are at a higher risk of having house fires and/or sustaining multiple degree burns due to accidents with these alternative lights. A visit to the Korle-Bu teaching hospital’s burns and reconstructive block last year helped the team see first-hand the damage that candle and kerosene lamp use has caused. Whole families lay in recovery rooms with life-threatening burns from accidents with candles/kerosene lamps. Many of these individuals and families lost their homes, and in some cases their loved ones, to these fires.

Kerosene lanterns are a poverty trap for these families. They may seem like the best alternative but serve only to retard health and burn holes in the pockets of these low income families who depend on them each night. Buying kerosene each day is expensive in the long run; both on the incomes and health of these people.


It is not uncommon in Ghana to see a child doing his homework with a kerosene lamp, or a candle, or for market vendors to use candles to try to illuminate their work spaces when it gets dark.

To these communities, reliance on candles and kerosene lamps seems to be an inevitable option or may even seem to them to be the solution to their problems. This reliance however has obvious disadvantages. Smoke from kerosene and candles cause respiratory illness and may subsequently cause death. Precious lives are also lost through fire outbreaks from these crude modes of light.


The Pilot

Earlier this year, in July, a pilot project was conducted in a small community called Akorlikope in the southeastern part of Ghana. Members of Liter of light Ghana built and installed lanterns in two homes as well as a local school. The event aimed at introducing the concept of solar lighting to the community, as well as to see how interested the community was in learning how to build these lights for themselves. By the end of the event, we were able to see first-hand the advantages of solar lighting to the people’s lives, as well as evaluate our performance as a team. We were pleasantly surprised to learn that every single member of the community was as involved us our team in building and installing the lights. The pilot was nothing short of successful, and seeing all the joy and gratitude expressed by members of the community only served to get the team even more excited for December.





The Solution

The ultimate solution to the issue would be a sustainable and inexpensive one, which is why the solar alternative will be beneficial to rural communities in Ghana.

The immediate goal of this project is to provide 100 homes with this cost-effective and long-lasting source of lighting in December. The aim is to get as much hands-on experience as possible, hence the Liter of Light Ghana team will be assembling the equipment under the supervision of electricians and engineers. The lights will then be taken to the various target communities and installed. Not all the assembling will be done prior to the project day. The team intends on making some materials available to teach the people of the Trawa community how to build these solar lanterns.




What does the project offer to the community?

Our combination of day, night and street lights provide a cheap, clean alternative to communities that totally removes the financial burden that kerosene places on these people who are largely very poor subsistence farmers at NO cost to them at all.

This project also significantly reduces the carbon footprints that each of these communities leave. Even though the CO2 and black carbon each of these communities emit from their use of kerosene lamps may seem insignificant, collectively kerosene is a major contributor to our total carbon dioxide pollution as a nation. We can contribute to reducing that significantly.

Our goal Is to raise $10,000 before the project date.This will go toward purchasing the materials needed to assemble the solar lanterns needed to light up a 100 homes, as well as 10 streetlights for community. Other costs include paying electricians and carpenters (who will be installing solar panels on roofs of homes), as well as logistics and transportation.


Risks & Challenges

One of our main challenges from the start of the project was ensuring that we had quality materials to build these lanterns. After extensive research we found and partnered with a Ghanaian-based company (Rikal Ghana Ltd) specializing in solar electrical products. To ensure each component would work efficiently as planned, we carried out a pilot project in a small community called Akorlikope, where we installed some of these lanterns with the aim of testing their efficiency and durability. The project was successful and the lanterns worked exactly how they were supposed to, and they continue to function well even till date. 

One challenge we'll need to address for the project will be ensuring that we have the most quality materials for the project. This will involve ensuring quality control throughout the project. Along with engineers from Rikal, we will be performing quality checks at every stage in the project to ensure the lanterns meet the quality standards to be as sustainable as possible.


The long-term plan/Sustainability

There’s an old adage that goes,

“give a man a fish and you feed him for a day; teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime..”

There is no greater gesture of service than teaching someone in need of something to be self-sufficient and sustainable in producing whatever it is they lack.  

One of the issues the team faced with past service projects was that these projects were not sufficiently sustainable. The team usually made donations of food and/or toiletries to the needy, or spent the day with kids at a local orphanage. Although these projects helped those in need, they were never sustainable enough. The donation of food items, which served these children well in the short term, was eventually going to run out, and the thought of that was unsettling. The team vowed from that point on to adopt a more sustainable approach to serving our community. The Liter of light ‘project 100 homes’ aims to fulfill this desire, and is our most sustainable project yet. The long-term goal would be to equip volunteers from each community with the know-how to be able to build solar lanterns themselves with the aim of fostering civic engagement and independence within the communities.


Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate you taking time to read about this project. We ask that you help us get this project out there and bring more folks on board. We ask that you please share this page with as many people you can. Help us make this a reality. Thank you, we appreciate you.

Support our social media pages:

https://www.facebook.com/literoflightgh/?ref=hl

https://twitter.com/literoflightgh

https://instagram.com/literoflight_ghana/
story_txt:
What is Liter of Light Ghana?

Liter of Light Ghana is a growing organization that seeks to provide eco-friendly, cost-effective solar lighting to communities that are deprived or have inadequate access to light. The technology that Liter of Light operates on is one that was developed by 'My Shelter Foundation', an NGO based in the Philippines. Founded by Illiac Diaz, the organization developed this innovative process that marries solar panels with recycled plastic bottles to produce clean, renewable lighting. Along with materials that can be sourced locally, these lights can be installed in electricity-deprived homes.In a country such as Ghana with well over 300 days of uninterrupted sunlight, it is expedient to harvest this natural source of energy to ameliorate the issue at hand. This technology has been used by the UN and has been adopted in some UNHCR camps worldwide.The liter of light Ghana team is comprised of young adults with a common goal of improving the lives of people in our beloved country, Ghana, and eventually beyond our country’s borders. The team plans on building and installing solar lanterns for 100 homes this December. Below are some of the lights the team will be building for the project:Daylight     Nightlight Streetlight




The Problem

Most people would agree that light is a basic necessity of life, to be seen as a right and not a privilege. Unfortunately, many people in the world (approx 1.3 billion) live without access to adequate electricity and thus light. Many small communities in Ghana (especially on the outskirts of town) are not even connected to the national electricity grid. When nighttime comes, most activity (and productivity) slows down considerably and even comes to a halt as there is no adequate lighting to help individuals and families carry out simple tasks. Children rely on candles or health hazardous kerosene lamps to study at night. Apart from straining their eyes to study under the dim, flickering lights these lamps offer, they put their healths at risk by inhaling the toxic kerosene fumes emanating from the lamps.Many families, who tend to use candles a  lot, are at a higher risk of having house fires and/or sustaining multiple degree burns due to accidents with these alternative lights. A visit to the Korle-Bu teaching hospital’s burns and reconstructive block last year helped the team see first-hand the damage that candle and kerosene lamp use has caused. Whole families lay in recovery rooms with life-threatening burns from accidents with candles/kerosene lamps. Many of these individuals and families lost their homes, and in some cases their loved ones, to these fires.Kerosene lanterns are a poverty trap for these families. They may seem like the best alternative but serve only to retard health and burn holes in the pockets of these low income families who depend on them each night. Buying kerosene each day is expensive in the long run; both on the incomes and health of these people.It is not uncommon in Ghana to see a child doing his homework with a kerosene lamp, or a candle, or for market vendors to use candles to try to illuminate their work spaces when it gets dark.To these communities, reliance on candles and kerosene lamps seems to be an inevitable option or may even seem to them to be the solution to their problems. This reliance however has obvious disadvantages. Smoke from kerosene and candles cause respiratory illness and may subsequently cause death. Precious lives are also lost through fire outbreaks from these crude modes of light.

 

The PilotEarlier this year, in July, a pilot project was conducted in a small community called Akorlikope in the southeastern part of Ghana. Members of Liter of light Ghana built and installed lanterns in two homes as well as a local school. The event aimed at introducing the concept of solar lighting to the community, as well as to see how interested the community was in learning how to build these lights for themselves. By the end of the event, we were able to see first-hand the advantages of solar lighting to the people’s lives, as well as evaluate our performance as a team. We were pleasantly surprised to learn that every single member of the community was as involved us our team in building and installing the lights. The pilot was nothing short of successful, and seeing all the joy and gratitude expressed by members of the community only served to get the team even more excited for December.The SolutionThe ultimate solution to the issue would be a sustainable and inexpensive one, which is why the solar alternative will be beneficial to rural communities in Ghana.The immediate goal of this project is to provide 100 homes with this cost-effective and long-lasting source of lighting in December. The aim is to get as much hands-on experience as possible, hence the Liter of Light Ghana team will be assembling the equipment under the supervision of electricians and engineers. The lights will then be taken to the various target communities and installed. Not all the assembling will be done prior to the project day. The team intends on making some materials available to teach the people of the Trawa community how to build these solar lanterns.What does the project offer to the community? Our combination of day, night and street lights provide a cheap, clean alternative to communities that totally removes the financial burden that kerosene places on these people who are largely very poor subsistence farmers at NO cost to them at all.This project also significantly reduces the carbon footprints that each of these communities leave. Even though the CO2 and black carbon each of these communities emit from their use of kerosene lamps may seem insignificant, collectively kerosene is a major contributor to our total carbon dioxide pollution as a nation. We can contribute to reducing that significantly.Our goal Is to raise $10,000 before the project date.This will go toward purchasing the materials needed to assemble the solar lanterns needed to light up a 100 homes, as well as 10 streetlights for community. Other costs include paying electricians and carpenters (who will be installing solar panels on roofs of homes), as well as logistics and transportation.Risks & ChallengesOne of our main challenges from the start of the project was ensuring that we had quality materials to build these lanterns. After extensive research we found and partnered with a Ghanaian-based company (Rikal Ghana Ltd) specializing in solar electrical products. To ensure each component would work efficiently as planned, we carried out a pilot project in a small community called Akorlikope, where we installed some of these lanterns with the aim of testing their efficiency and durability. The project was successful and the lanterns worked exactly how they were supposed to, and they continue to function well even till date. One challenge we'll need to address for the project will be ensuring that we have the most quality materials for the project. This will involve ensuring quality control throughout the project. Along with engineers from Rikal, we will be performing quality checks at every stage in the project to ensure the lanterns meet the quality standards to be as sustainable as possible.The long-term plan/SustainabilityThere’s an old adage that goes, “give a man a fish and you feed him for a day; teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime..”There is no greater gesture of service than teaching someone in need of something to be self-sufficient and sustainable in producing whatever it is they lack.  One of the issues the team faced with past service projects was that these projects were not sufficiently sustainable. The team usually made donations of food and/or toiletries to the needy, or spent the day with kids at a local orphanage. Although these projects helped those in need, they were never sustainable enough. The donation of food items, which served these children well in the short term, was eventually going to run out, and the thought of that was unsettling. The team vowed from that point on to adopt a more sustainable approach to serving our community. The Liter of light ‘project 100 homes’ aims to fulfill this desire, and is our most sustainable project yet. The long-term goal would be to equip volunteers from each community with the know-how to be able to build solar lanterns themselves with the aim of fostering civic engagement and independence within the communities.
Other Ways You Can Help We appreciate you taking time to read about this project. We ask that you help us get this project out there and bring more folks on board. We ask that you please share this page with as many people you can. Help us make this a reality. Thank you, we appreciate you.
